Hi @ourweb4 - I'm afraid between my real job and my family I don't have time to examine all your code. And, as I've said, I don't think the problem _is_ your code, but the request you're getting.

You can log the request in cloudwatch by setting an environmental variable on your lambda. the variable name is `LAMBDA_NET_SERIALIZER_DEBUG` and the value needs to be `true`

When this is on your lambda, if you make a request that fails, the JSON that your lambda got sent will appear in the Cloudwatch logs, and you can see the whole request - not just the error.

Without that there's not much more we can do I'm afraid.

Thanks

Steven
I logged into cloudwatch, I dont see where I set the environmental variable?

You set the environmental variable on the lambda - there's an environmental variable section where it can be placed.

After you've saved the change to the lambda, you need to cause the failure, and then the skillrequest JSON will appear in Cloudwatch.

Okay so @ourweb4 - can you please delete that message, those tokens are live and will allow people to act as your skill.

What you can see though is that you're getting `AMAZON.FallbackIntent` - which is what you receive when what the user has says doesn't match any of your intents. So there are no slots, which mean your code will break if it assumes the slot value exists.

What you need is to ensure you only run your code when it's your `Country` intent that's been invoked. Something like `if(intentRequest.Intent.Name == 'Country')` or whatever works for your skill

Hope this helps

I can add some a few more tests to demonstrate.  It's definitely a style thing.  Some people love them, others not so much. In this case I almost didn't comment at all because I actually agree a string would make the ResponseBuilder `.Ask` calls a lot better for reprompt (I constantly forget when I write those calls) - but I think the value is in overloads on the ResponseBuilder method, not an operator. If you're creating the object in isolation the constructor is so small there's no value from an operator, and part of the library benefit is it helps you learn the request/response syntax so it's easier to read in Amazon's tools which are almost always raw JSON - reprompt is an object you see all the time.

In terms of "awesomeness", operators can definitely deliver - the two instances Alexa.NET has of implicit operators currently:

IntentSignature - Amazon give us the signature as a string, so I didn't really want to complicate the JSON conversion, but there was little benefit to the string without the ability to parse it out into an object model to expose the detail to the developer. Still unsure this was the right call compared to a .Parse method on the object.
https://github.com/timheuer/alexa-skills-dotnet/blob/master/Alexa.NET/Request/IntentSignature.cs

APLValue in Alexa.NET.APL - the APL library relies heavily on implicit conversion; every property in every object can be either a specific type or a data binding string, so with no union types in .NET constructing objects was painful. To make the library usable for all but the most simple example, I added implicit operators to handle my "value" object
https://github.com/stoiveyp/Alexa.NET.APL/blob/master/Alexa.NET.APL/APLValue_T.cs

I think it's unfair to just say it's a style preference, it's about the right tool for the job.

Just been busy at 'real job' :-) -- I'm all for improvements, just would want it to be improvements consistent across the entire library rather than just specific areas; meaning 'is there other places where the pattern should be implemented so it doesn't look like we just cherry picked' kind of approach.

Totally understand and no pressure intended.  Consistency is important, but even more so when you're building a library for other developers to consume. 1) Leave everything the same and abandon the PR
2) Use an implicit conversion operator, which was what the original PR had in it
3) Modify the ResponseBuilder class to accept strings in addition to Reprompt, which is what my most recent changes add.

I'm happy to make any sweeping changes that you see are needed to keep the library consistent.

Thanks!

Hi @kenbrower would you mind if I asked for a little clarification? APL and body templates are two different techniques to rendering data on screen; with APL being the preferred mechanism from Amazon these days due to its increased flexibility - but they don't work in conjunction with one another.

If you're using body templates, then the data has to come from filling in the fields in the template and attaching that to the render template directive.

If you're using APL then the main template has a "payload" parameter - and that refers to the data sources tab in the designer, so all your fields will be of the style  `${payload.dataSourceName.fieldName}`

If you want to have support for APL within Alexa.NET skills - then that's available through the Alexa.NET.APL NuGet package at https://github.com/stoiveyp/Alexa.NET.APL and you can use the RenderDocument directive, which has a data sources property in it for your data. More than happy to answer questions about APL support there

I realise this is quite a wordy answer, but I want to make sure we're all talking about the same thing, and that the issues are in the right place to best get resolved for you 👍

Hi @stoiveyp . Thank you for the reply and the useful information. After reading your message I realize I was mixing the two and in fact what we have been using is just the body templates which I am now assuming was the precursor to APL.

I'll work on setting up a test using the RenderDocument directive and see if we can figure out how to get that working. If you don't mind one more naive question... When you use the Alexa developer authoring tool where is the actual template JSON and how do you send that with the RenderDocument directive?  It makes sense that the data is referenced in a payload parameter but I'm not understanding where the actual template definition resides.

Thanks again for the quick reply!

@kenbrower really good question - the tool is only a way of creating the APL templates, to see the template you're creating with the tools there is the toggle button (highlighted below)

![templateButton](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/147125/60835393-e2a58c80-a1ba-11e9-83da-7090747cbfe1.jpg)

Once you have a template you're happy with - that template needs to be copied/saved out of the designer and stored somewhere the skill can access it (S3 bucket, local file etc). This can then be used to deserialize the JSON into a Document object that can be used with the directive.

Hope this helps.

Hi @stoiveyp ! 

Here's the a piece of a [post](https://alexa.uservoice.com/forums/906892-alexa-skills-developer-voice-and-vote/suggestions/36665794-add-additional-permission-scopes-to-alexa-response): 
"Currently an Alexa response includes permission scopes for "payments:autopay_consent" and "alexa::devices:all:geolocation:read" if the Skill manifest requests those permissions. The status will either be "GRANTED" or "DENIED". If "DENIED" the Skill can request the user enable the permission."

In summary I need to check if **context.System.user.permissions.scopes['alexa::devices:all:geolocation:read'].status** is **GRANTED**.

You can also see this doc "detect-which-specific-permissions-are-needed": 
https://developer.amazon.com/fr/docs/custom-skills/location-services-for-alexa-skills.html#detect-which-specific-permissions-are-needed

I hope this will answer to your question 👍

Yeah that's the problem - the converter has to be added to the lambda before your function handler gets invoked - otherwise when your request tries to create the right SkillRequest, there's no code for that kind of request available and generates the error.

To fix it create a constructor for the lambda, then move the converter registration into the constructor - that way when the function is invoked the converter is already registered and it should create the right SkillRequest.

Hope this helps

The idea of a BadRequest type would be to handle valid request objects, but that have a type that the skill can't handle. We're not allowing bad requests to get through into the skill code - we're identifying to the developer they don't have the setup to handle a valid request coming in.

The empty request example is not valid for the object model we're giving the developers, and so in that case, an exception does make sense.

> The empty request example is not valid for the object model we're giving the developers, and so in that case, an exception does make sense.

As long as it is not silently ignored like it is implemented now, I am happy 👍
That's not something we can control as it's JSON deserialization within the host environment, but we don't actively hide any exceptions. Hope this clears things up.

Questions are absolutely the right thing - makes sure we're not making any incorrect assumptions.

The reason it's bad practice is because it's not a valid SkillRequest, so the correct response is an exception - stopping the flow of the code and ensuring valid logic isn't run for something that shouldn't be allowed.

The issue you have is that you're trying to allow an invalid request - which shouldn't be able to happen, and isn't something the package should force every developer to deal with, so as it's a specific use case - you'll have to handle it locally, rather than making it a problem all users of the package will have to be aware of.

Does that help clarify things?

We had this exact issue when they changed the DateTime format for the Alexa simulator - suddenly none of the skills could be tested, because they changed the rules around date formatting. Rather than turning the field into a string and allowing JSON.NET to put any possible value in there, we changed the converter to allow a mix of the two date time formats. This way the correct information (a valid date) was still placed in the request - and invalid date formats caused an exception.

We work within the realm of what JSON.Net lets us do, and sometimes it's a judgement call. But this argument can absolutely be applied to all packages - some people, I'm sure, don't want a FileNotFoundException when System.IO can't find a file and would prefer a null return - but you do what you believe adheres to the best rules for the majority of the consumers and best practice within .NET, there's always a case where it doesn't fit exactly, and that's part of open source.

And actually, that's a good time to mention that our licence allows you to fork and alter this default logic without any repercussions (something I've stuck to with all the Alexa.Net extensions too) so you're absolutely able to make it work specifically for you without any concern.

Unless there's more code to be submitted - I suggest we close this PR, as I believe the decision has been thoroughly discussed and we're now having a more general conversation about package maintenance, which I think is best put into an issue if we want to carry on.

Any problems with us moving forward that way?

Hi @JJLucena - your SSML has to start with a \<speak\> tag, otherwise it's not valid SSML.

Alternatively you can use the Speech object in Alexa.NET.Response.SSML to take away some of the markup maintenance.

```csharp
using Alexa.NET.Response.Ssml;
...
soundLink.Ssml = new Speech(new Audio("https://s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/afinadorcromaticosounds/piano/A_piano.mp3")).ToXml();
```

Hi @cwcoomes - if I'm reading the code correctly it will currently only work for intents.

In your second line `(incomingRequest.Request as IntentRequest)` will produce a null output for LaunchRequest objects, or anything other than an intent. This means the `.Intent.Name` part of the statement will be against a null object and generate a NullReferenceException

I'd move that line to inside the case statement for IntentRequest and remove the subsequent line, as you already have an intentRequest being generated with the statement `case IntentRequest intent`

Hi @shannonlowder - apologies if I'm asking an obvious question. The response SessionAttributes is a dictionary object - so I would expect the employee and visitor keys to be added somewhere, is there a SessionAttributes.Add earlier on in the function?

As an aside when you're maintaining state you might find it easier to only use one session object. If you grab the session from the request at the beginning of your function - use that throughout the function - and then set the response session to the same object on output, then you're not having to try and transfer settings/values between the two; I find it makes session maintenance easier.
Do you also set ShouldEndSession to false?

Hi @senpAi95 - I'm afraid you're not able to change the intent of a request, what will happen is that you'll send the updated intent in the response and that will most likely generate a System.ExceptionEncountered request.

Progressive response is different to sending speech as a regular response, as there's no type requirement. This means you can use the raw SSML if you'd rather and place it into the string version of SendSpeech. It will work as expected.

Here's a link to the relevant documentation. Look a little above where this link sends you, at the "directive.speech" section, for more detailed information about what's acceptable.

[Amazon Alexa - Sending the user a progressive response](https://developer.amazon.com/docs/custom-skills/send-the-user-a-progressive-response.html#directive-response)

Hi @rabejens, this is definitely possible with Alexa.Net and I'm happy to help figure it out.

Couple of things I'd like to check before we get into specifics.

First of all, does your code keep sending back a DialogDelegate until all the slots are filled?

Your skill will receive an intent request after a DialogDelegate response has asked for the next empty slot. Your skill will need to check each time if there are still slots to fill, and send another DialogDelegate if there are any missing. This loop needs to continue until all the slots are filled in.

If you already have this loop, is your skill sending back an updated intent with the DialogDelegate? Although optional, without the updated intent object in the response, Alexa won't keep track of any updated slots and the skill ends up with previously answered questions being returned as empty next time around.

Let me know about these two areas and if everything checks out we can get into some specifics.

I already accounted for the slot filling for one intent and it works. I'll describe what I have so far and where I am stuck:

- I ask my skill: "Put foo in bar"
- The skill receives the `RelationshipIntent` with both slots `thing` and `parent` filled with `foo` and `bar` respectively
  - If I ask something like "Manage a relationship" it receives the intent with both slots empty, so it sends `DialogDelegate`s and asks the user until both slots are filled.
- It queries a DynamoDB table if `foo` and `bar` both exist
  - If they exist, it puts the relationship in and answers: `bar is now the parent of foo`.
  - If one or both don't exist, it puts three commands onto a list in the session (Create `foo`, create `bar`, make `bar` a parent of `foo`)
  - Then, it says something like `foo and bar do not exist. Do you want me to create them?`
  - If I answer "yes", it goes into the `YesIntent`, gets the first command from the list (which is "Create `foo`" in this example)
  - Now, I want to forge a `NewThing` intent with the `thing` slot filled accordingly, and delegate to it, as if I asked the skill "Create foo"

And at this point I am stuck. I even created a simple skill which has the intents `Foo` and `Bar`, and if I say `Foo` it should redirect to the `Bar` intent, but my Echo still answers with "There was a problem with the skill". When I test it in the Alexa management console, I *do* get a JSON object back that looks like it is the correct `Bar` skill.

Here is what I do (it is F# code with some shortcuts thrown in, but I verified that they work as intended):

```fsharp
let intent = new Intent()
intent.Slots <- new Dictionary<string, Slot>()
let slots = intent.Slots
match nextTask with
| NewThing thing ->
	intent.Name <- "NewThing"
	let slot = new Slot()
	slot.Name <- "thing"
	slot.Value <- thing
	slots.Add("thing", slot)
| // others
let attribs = session
			  |> attribs
			  |> Map.remove "yes" // This was the list of new commands that got in here on the "yes"
			  // pendingTasks is just a list of tasks to fulfill later. box puts them into a System.Object
			  // so I can serialize them with JSON.net
			  // I am doing this explicitly because deserializing does not always discover the correct
			  // object I want to have
			  |> Map.add "pending" (pendingTasks |> box |> JsonConvert.SerializeObject |> box)
session.Attributes <- new Dictionary<string, obj>(attribs |> Map.toSeq |> dict)
ResponseBuilder.DialogDelegate(session, intent)
```

So, what am I missing here?

Apologies for misunderstanding @rabejens 

Unfortunately this isn't possible. Nothing to do with the library, it's the behaviour of the Dialog Delegate

Quoting from [Dialog Interface Reference](https://developer.amazon.com/docs/custom-skills/dialog-interface-reference.html#delegate)

> Note that you cannot change intents when returning a Dialog directive, so the intent name and set of slots must match the intent sent to your skill.

After some googling, I found out I missed the following:

```fsharp
[<LambdaSerializer(typeof<Amazon.Lambda.Serialization.Json.JsonSerializer>)>]
```

Or, in C#:

```csharp
[LambdaSerializer(typeof(Amazon.Lambda.Serialization.Json.JsonSerializer))]
```
 and the dependency on `Amazon.Lambda.Serialization.Json`

It would be nice if this was stated in the readme, too.
Where do you put that? I'm getting the same error.

You put that between the using statements and your namespace:

```csharp
using Amazon.Lambda.Core;

// Assembly attribute to enable the Lambda function's JSON input to be converted into a .NET class.
[assembly: LambdaSerializer(typeof(Amazon.Lambda.Serialization.Json.JsonSerializer))]

namespace MySkill
```

This is generated for you if you use the VS AWS Extension and create an AWS Lambda Project, or if you use the dotnet CLI tooling to create a lambda project (docs can be found here https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/lambda-dotnet-coreclr-deployment-package.html  )

Hope this helps
Thanks, that did it :)

@sanjeevSOPRA because of the way type is determined within the JSON - there's a lot of logic built around using Newtonsoft within the current version of the assembly and its extensions.

Regardless of .NET framework version, you have to use the JsonSerializer with Alexa.NET or the skill will start to throw exceptions when it tries to successfully deserialize the object model.

Hi @nishantpant - happy to help you work through this. The issue I had when I was working with the dialogs was not sending back the updated intent and thinking the state was being kept by Alexa.

Alexa skills don't keep track of the intent for you, the intent request receives the state that the intent is currently in, allows you to manipulate or fill in the blanks if you can, then you have to send it back as part of the dialog delegate - otherwise you end up with a blank intent again and Alexa starts from scratch; The dialog delegate and elicit slot responses just give you a way of asking for the information based on dialog configuration rather than having to build that speech directly into the skill code.

The Dialog.Delegate it's talking about is a directive in the JSON, in this case generated using the DialogDelegateDirective class in the Alexa.NET code, which is what the ResponseBuilder.DialogDelegate method is doing with the information you send it.

That's a general overview to help with how it's supposed to work, but when you say it doesn't work - is it that it's not filling in the slots properly (a sign of needing an updated intent as described) or are you getting a specific error back?

that's what I've been looking for! Did you use it in an ASP.NET Core Web API? How do you go about integrating this?

When you get the request, Amazon sign the request with two headers:

*    Signature
*    SignatureCertChainUrl

So if you run the RequestVerification.Verify method, with the values from these two headers as the first two parameters, and the body of the request as the last, it should return a boolean value telling you whether or not the signature is valid.

For more information on the steps Amazon ask you to take, read up on the [Amazon Documentation for hosting a skill](https://developer.amazon.com/public/solutions/alexa/alexa-skills-kit/docs/developing-an-alexa-skill-as-a-web-service#checking-the-signature-of-the-request)

And as ever, let me know if you run into any trouble and I'll try and help out.

Updated the dialog branch to honour the entity resolution pulled into the master branch

Intents, slots and entity resolution have been moved back to the Request namespace in the latest commit.

Entity resolution was kept in the request namespace because it had to stay in line with where Intent was and brought in on its own that was the Request namespace. This PR changes how the entire Intent structure is used, making it part of both request and response, so the namespace change only made sense at this stage - but I knew it was a risk because of the size of the break it would cause.

It's not problematic keeping them in the Request namespace. It does niggle at me that Intent isn't a request object now but is in the request namespace - but lowing the barrier to added value is always going to be more important 😄

Good observation @bmatthews99 -- the ResponseBuilder is intended to be the simple helper method.  A "tell" is a fire/forget thing and thus the session end is assumed to be True.  Contradict that to an "ask" response where there also might be a reprompt, but at a minimum you are expecting a second request from the user...this will automatically keep the session alive.

There is no reason, though that an overload couldn't have that specific property exposed, but in creating the helper method for simplicity, the intent was to only have to set the minimum needed to create the response.  Creating up a full SkillResponse is still possible and you can set all the attributes of the response individually.

> .NET Standard vs. .NET Core -- I'm curious why you think .NET Standard is better here?

As .NetStandard is the most portable profile for interoperability between .Net runtimes.  .NetCore is very far from a replacement of .NetFull and it still does not work fully under Mono. With the project being under .NetStandard (compatible as a PCL library) we can use existing tooling and environments.

> Project Icon -- I'd like to see something more generic (or none at all really, but the feather doesn't make sense to me :-))

It's a quill. I added that as the name "Alexa" comes from the Great Library of Alexandria. The icon doesn't need to represent anything, we can create meaning - Alexa is already an abstract ideal anyway. e.g. https://github.com/Fody/Fody

> XML Docs -- I was going to start newer comments that hopefully would drive support for readthedocs.org

What system did you have in mind?

> .NetStandard

No version of .Net works fully under Mono as it is incomplete, hence why its proving hard work making Umbraco work on it, however making the Umbraco.Core run cross platform has been achieved rather easily and it works as expected on .NetCore on Linux. I would lean on the side of building on top of .NetCore as the framework but support .NetStandard as the standard & any issues with it running on Linux etc be raised at the appropriate locations since the target of Microsoft is now to make it work entirely as expected cross-platform, it is essentially the next level replacement & therefore if building something new which could be rather underpinning as a library then it should be as future-proof as possible by considering the big picture :)

> Project Icon

Ah I see, thats new to me haha, I was in the same group as Tim & though it was a feather or something didn't really pay it much attention, why not make it something similar to what Amazon might already have for their services? They must have a media pack as well anyway

> Documentation

I agree, readthedocs is nicely readable and usable :)

@jaddie 

>  I would lean on the side of building on top of .NetCore

That would disregard 99% of the .Net ecosystem. .NetStandard is the replacement of the PCL's which run under the .NetCore and .NetFull runtimes. 

From https://github.com/dotnet/standard/blob/master/docs/faq.md:

>.NET Standard is a set of APIs that all .NET platforms have to implement. This unifies the .NET platforms and prevents future fragmentation.
>.NET Standard 2.0 will be implemented by .NET Framework, .NET Core, and Xamarin. For .NET Core, this will add many of the existing APIs that have been requested.
>.NET Standard 2.0 includes a compatibility shim for .NET Framework binaries, significantly increasing the set of libraries that you can reference from your .NET Standard libraries.
>.NET Standard will replace Portable Class Libraries (PCLs) as the tooling story for building multi-platform .NET libraries.

I talked with my counterparts on the .NET team and now agree with @Silvenga  :-) -- let's move to .NET Standard (I *think* my project here is already on that based on the project.json) but some of the naming in the tooling is still a bit confusing for me.  Let's do it!

I appreciate having more options!

Though I have some comments:

- I'm used Google search, as that's what the actual site redirects to for reaching the reference.
- Might be nice to make this an option, can add a setting.
- Your DuckDuckGo searches seems to be just adding the website name, which can sometimes lead to weird forum post answers. Would be better to make it point to the websites we intend, and I'd think better to give a list of options than use ! to auto go to the first result. Ex: ```https://duckduckgo.com/?q=site%3Aprocessing.org+```
- Similar to above, there seems to be an unneeded ```%5C``` in the processing url.

The `!processing` prefix is 100% equivalent to `site:processing.org`. If necessary, we could add `inurl:reference` to ensure it doesn't go anywhere else (btw, this also happens with the current Google search).

On the other hand, `!p5` is NOT equivalent to `site:p5js.org` because that site's search is hash-based. In other words, in DuckDuckGo `!p5` works and `site:p5js.org` doesn't.

The `%5C` is needed because is what makes the automatic redirection (not necessary in `!p5` because, again, it's hash-based). If you omit it you see the search results.

You can try it manually by going to https://duckduckgo.com and searching for:
1) `!processing frameRate` (a more strict alternative would be `!processing inurl:reference frameRate` which is equivalent to https://duckduckgo.com/?q=site%3Aprocessing.org+inurl%3Areference+frameRate)
2) `!processing \frameRate` (stricter alternative: `!processing \inurl:reference frameRate` or https://duckduckgo.com/?q=site%3Aprocessing.org+%5Cinurl%3Areference+frameRate)
3) `!p5 frameRate` (no alternative)

P.S. On search results v automatic redirect: I prefer the redirect because it's more similar to the behavior of the original IDE
P.P.S. Expanded the manual examples above

Are you setting processing.path ?

From the readme:

> What if you cannot, or do not want to add Processing to your path?
> 
> Simply modify the processing.path setting to follow the path to wherever processing is installed on your machine. Be sure to remember to keep the processing-java at the end of the path!
> 
> To change settings in VSCode, here is a link to the official documentation.
> 
> **(Remember, for Windows be sure to turn any `"\"` into `"\\"`!)**

Single slashes on windows are part of codes, like how `"\n"` is a new line. `"\\"` is translated to `\` and single slashes are just removed.

If processing is set up in your path (as you said, you can Windows+R and type just processing and it runs) you should NOT set a value to the processing.path VSCode setting.

So when you say "I have set the path" - do you have any value assigned to the processing.path setting? If so, what?

@TobiahZ Oh, I thought you meant the env `%path%` variable, but it still works.
Anyways, I just realised what you said

> Single slashes on Windows are part of codes, like how "\n" is a new line. "\\" is translated to \ and single slashes are just removed.

That explains everything!

> @TobiahZ Oh, I thought you meant the env `%path%` variable, but it still works.
> Anyways, I just realised what you said
> 
> > Single slashes on Windows are part of codes, like how "\n" is a new line. "\" is translated to \ and single slashes are just removed.
> 
> That explains everything!

could I ask how you fixed the problem?

@lucasoeth  I can't speak for @wooden-utensil , but I assume the issue was having single slashes in a file URI.

Example: `C:\Users\MyUser\Desktop\Project`

However, on Windows, the single backslash character `\` is special. It's used to insert special symbols.

Example: `This is on line one\nThis is line two` would be rendered as:

```
This is on line one
This is line two
```

Since a `\n` is replaced with a new line character.

Single slashes are simply automatically removed if they aren't followed by one of the key letters it's looking for.

Hence why `C:\Users\MyUser\Desktop\Project` might turn into `C:UsersMyUserDesktopProject`

Thus, you want to use the special character `\\` to create a single backslash.

If you are using the processing.path setting variable on windows, make sure your folder location URI uses double slashes!

Hey there.

This is a bug with the new VSCode Live Share plugin I believe. The path is correct for Windows, but the problem is that your VSCode is running both the Mac/Linux args AND the Windows ones.

The problem is not caused by this extension, but rather your copy of VSCode plus another extension you have installed.

See these issues: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/50006 https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/50299

I found out that it was changing the default terminal to bash in my settings.json that's causing the bug.
`"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Program Files\\Git\\bin\\bash.exe",`

This is an error message from Processing, not from the extension itself.

You seem to have opened your project from a "projects" folder, and then have you actual project in a subfolder from there. The extension runs the project from the base folder you have open (How else would it know which sub project you're supposed to run?)

Since you are running it from a base folder (that I'll bet is named "processing") it's looking for the FolderName.pde file.

@fahadachaudhry looks great 🙂
I can repro, the fix is probably updating `typescript` or `@types/node` (v10 seems safe)

Got it working by removing '^' from the version numbers for both the "@types/node" and "typescript" entries in the devDependencies section of the package.json, deleting node_modules directory and running npm install again. 
New devDependencies entry in package.json:
```js
"devDependencies": {
    "@types/node": "7.0.10",
    "typescript": "2.2.1",
    "vscode-theme-generator": "*"
}
```
Removing node_modules, reinstalling modules and running. 
```bash
rm -rf ./node_modules/ && npm install
npm start
```
Doesn't seem like a long-term solution, given the old versions used for both these dependencies, but might help anyone in the same situation.

Also a relatively new addition is to flash the symbol briefly when you go to it, this is particularly useful when you go to the same symbol (eg. variable definition is the only reference). This would remove the background flash and just flash the blue focus color:

```
"editor.symbolHighlightBackground": "#0000",
"editor.symbolHighlightBorder": "#399ef4"
```

What do these color keys actually do? I can't see any changes after adding this setting:

```
  "workbench.colorCustomizations": {
    "tab.activeModifiedBorder": "#ff0000",
    "tab.inactiveModifiedBorder": "#00ff00"
  },
```

You also need `"workbench.editor.highlightModifiedTabs": true`. With that on, it will show a colored top border on dirty/modified tabs. There’s an animated demo [in the release notes](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_29#_highlight-modified-tabs).

It's a known bug. It affects more that punctuation. I can't find the issue, but the way to fix it is to assign foreground color of each theme 

like this:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/theme-monokai-dimmed/themes/dimmed-monokai-color-theme.json#L58

or that:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/theme-monokai-dimmed/themes/dimmed-monokai-color-theme.json#L390

Well foreground is being set:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/40615615-5ab013ea-623c-11e8-9cb0-449db598fcb6.png)

It's just that the string scope is more specific so it overrides it. I think the only fix is to color all the brackets that could appear within an interpolated string.
Fixed, let me know if you find other similar cases

No, I mean assigning foreground of those scopes that I linked above with the same color as `editor.foreground` is the official way of fixing this bug.

Dot: `` `text ${func.length} text` ``

Yeah as far as I know you can't do this as the textmate engine relies on the native oniguruma regex library. You could do it if you had a server that could run the native lib of course but that's a little more tricky.

Another issue with a web-based interface is you need more files than just the json to actually publish the extension. So you'd want to define exactly what your web interface is trying to accomplish before you get started, that would determine how hard it is going to be to implement :smile:

Another option is a hybrid of the multiple-level deriving:

```
background
  > selection, +x% light
    > sidebar selection background
    ...
  > strong background, +x% light
    > sidebar background
    ....
```

Minimum requirements is just background here, but it's recommended that you fill in all the "core colors" (selection, strong background, focus, etc.).

I did this for my Themes [here](https://github.com/gerane/VSCodeThemes). I just used PowerShell to take cropped screenshots for the Theme screenshot and Theme icon. I also auto generated all of my package.json values. It would be great if you could do this programmatically just based on the input colors in some way. 

My way still required a manual action per theme (switching to target theme), but I was also intentionally doing it manually because I was also looking for bugs caused by the conversion. After I changed theme, I just ran a command and it would take screenshots and update json etc. Then I just inspected everything looking for issues.

I quickly threw this together after I put my daughter to bed. In the themes I was working with, I didn't have an easy list of the color codes. I just wrote this in PowerShell, so I'd assume there has to be something similar in js. The better way to do it would likely be to take the colors as input instead, so $Green instead $CommentColor etc. The one issue with this, is I am just creating a bitmap and replacing the text colors, so it isn't a real screenshot of the theme in Code. 

I am also not 100% sure how the colors translate to PowerShell, so the colors I used might not be totally correct, but I was just wanting to kind of make an example.

```powershell
function New-ThemeImage
{
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param
    (
        $Filename,
        $BackgroundColor,
        $ForegroundColor,
        $StringColor,
        $CommentColor,
        $KeywordColor,
        $FunctionColor,
        $FunctionCallColor,
        $ClassColor
    )

    Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing

    $Bitmap = new-object System.Drawing.Bitmap 300,230
    $font = new-object System.Drawing.Font Consolas,14

    $Gfx = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($Bitmap)
    $Gfx.FillRectangle($BackgroundColor,0,0,$Bitmap.Width,$Bitmap.Height)

    $Gfx.DrawString('function',$font,$KeywordColor,10,10)
    $Gfx.DrawString(' Test-Function',$font,$ClassColor,90,10)
    $Gfx.DrawString('{',$font,$ForegroundColor,10,35)
    $Gfx.DrawString('# Test Comment',$font,$CommentColor,40,60)
    $Gfx.DrawString('$',$font,$KeywordColor,40,85)
    $Gfx.DrawString('var',$font,$FunctionColor,50,85)
    $Gfx.DrawString('= ',$font,$ForegroundColor,90,85)
    $Gfx.DrawString('"Hello World"',$font,$StringColor,110,85)
    $Gfx.DrawString('$',$font,$KeywordColor,40,110)
    $Gfx.DrawString('var',$font,$FunctionColor,50,110)
    $Gfx.DrawString('.Replace',$font,$FunctionCallColor,80,110)
    $Gfx.DrawString('(',$font,$KeywordColor,160,110)
    $Gfx.DrawString('"Hello "',$font,$StringColor,170,110)
    $Gfx.DrawString(',',$font,$KeywordColor,250,110)
    $Gfx.DrawString('""',$font,$StringColor,260,110)
    $Gfx.DrawString(')',$font,$KeywordColor,280,110)
    $Gfx.DrawString('Return ',$font,$KeywordColor,40,160)
    $Gfx.DrawString('$',$font,$KeywordColor,110,160)
    $Gfx.DrawString('var',$font,$FunctionColor,120,160)
    $Gfx.DrawString('}',$font,$ForegroundColor,10,185)

    $Gfx.Dispose()
    $Bitmap.Save($Filename)
}


function Convert-ColorCode
{
    param($Color)
    [System.Drawing.SolidBrush]::new([System.Drawing.ColorTranslator]::FromHtml($Color))
}

$Theme = @{
    BackgroundColor   = Convert-ColorCode '#151B24'
    ForegroundColor   = Convert-ColorCode '#efefef'
    StringColor       = Convert-ColorCode '#DA6771'
    CommentColor      = Convert-ColorCode '#4A5160'
    KeywordColor      = Convert-ColorCode '#399EF4'
    FunctionColor     = Convert-ColorCode '#21C5C7'
    FunctionCallColor = Convert-ColorCode '#fff099'
    ClassColor        = Convert-ColorCode '#21C5C7'
}

New-ThemeImage @Theme -Filename  "C:\Test.png"
```

I had a lot of issues when converting themes from tmthemes. Code doesn't support as many color codes as other editors.

A decent number of themes had colors that were bright red or converted to some other crazy color.

AFAIK vscode only supports 6 and 8 digit hex notation, the documentation isn't too comprehensive atm.

I found a bunch of themes broke because they expected text background color to be supported, but vscode doesn't.

I do have the same problem. Somehow the raw html contents get mangled.

So in the document I have the following:

``` html
<iframe width="640" height="480" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/xx" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
```

This appears in the output of the blog post itself just fine. However, on the index of the blog (i.e. if I put that video before `.. more::`), it will become the following:

``` html
<iframe width="640" height="480" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/xx" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen=""/>
```

Firefox is then not able to cope with the HTML and does not display anything beyond that. For me the fix is to have no videos before `.. more::`, but that is a bit sad as I would like to show the video up front.

Currently tagline string is passed directly to the templating engine and rendered as a string inside `

` tags. Take a look at `tinkerer/themes/boilerplate/layout.html`. If you want a richer tagline, you can currently create a new `_template/layout.html` in your blog, have that inherit from the theme's `layout.html`, and override the `header` block. You should have something like this in the `_templates/layout.html` of your blog: ``` {%- extends "!layout.html" -%} {%- block header -%}

{{ shorttitle|e }}

--> Add whatever you like here <--
{% endblock -%} ``` This is pretty much the header block from `layout.html`, with the tagline replaced by whatever you want to put in there. Tinkerer is doing something similar with the `page.html` template for the Tinkerer blog (at http://tinkerer.me). Take a look at `/blog/_templates/page.html` for this project. I have to think a bit about what would be the best way to more easily enable this. reStructuredText might be trickier because of the way Sphinx works (though I guess we could go directly to docutils for this instead of Sphinx). Raw html might cause other issues, as it would bypass escaping which we get for free now from Jinja. If we would pass in raw html, taglines containing characters like `<`, `>` etc. would break the html. I do agree with you that richer tagline should be easier to achieve, but I want to make sure it's done right. Hopefully the steps above will work for you, and I'll think some more about the best way this can be achieved.

The reason I moved sphinx-build to external process is that in newer versions, Sphinx calls sys.exit on failure, which also terminates Tinkerer when running in-proc, and we don't always want that.

I see. I've been looking at the Sphinx source code and the only place where they exit on error is https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/src/71b0148df7589e7fe34fb081ad7f3da4b9ca22b2/sphinx/cmdline.py?at=default#cl-202 Did you mean that? However, that looks more like a bug to me, because everywhere else in the `cmdline.main` function they return the status code.

This was recently introduced in the latest Sphinx version so I have no idea whether it is a bug or the way going forward for Sphinx to respond to issues. Anyway, running sphinx-build in-proc now can prematurely terminate tinkerer and in general it should be safer to call it as a separate process. I understand there are some limitations but as long as Sphinx is shipped as a tool not a library, I'd say it's better to do it this way.

Is this the full output? Sphinx always fails to load pickled environment because we're not pickling it for Tinkerer build. Pickle is used for incremental build in Sphinx. We don't support incremental build in Tinkerer because we need to rebuild all pages (to make sure navbar/widgets like categories and tags/aggregated pages are all up to date).

Sphinx always spat out this error but usually build continues just fine. Is this not happening in your case?

Fixed with ca2e378c1e0bd47b9b1d6ada1a062b42bd24b127. Issue was Sphinx started using sys.argv instead of arguments passed to main. Tinkerer invokes Sphinx by passing in constructed argv to sphinx.main, which doesn't work anymore.

This looks like an upstream bug. Tinkerer runs each post page through PyQuery to patch some relative links and other stuff. Looks like in the process, `<iframe ...></iframe>` gets turned into `<iframe />`. This seems to be the reason browser doesn't read this correctly. There is no particular logic for dealing with iframes, so this is either PyQuery or lxml issue that it collapses open and closed tags into a single one. I'll dig some more into it if I have time to spare, but I doubt I can locally fix it in Tinkerer...

Looks like this happens with any open/closed tags with no content. On the other hand, there seems to be a simple fix: just add a space between the iframe tags. The parser will consider it as content and it will no longer collapse them into a single tag.

I'll Won't Fix this issue since there is a simple workaround and it's an upstream problem anyway.

Tinkerer example, that causes this behavior: ``` rst Example ======= .. author:: default .. author_url:: default .. categories:: none .. tags:: none .. comments:: ... Heading A --------- ... Heading B --------- Heading B.1 ^^^^^^^^^^^ ... .. more:: ... Heading B.2 ^^^^^^^^^^^ - ... - ... - ... Heading C --------- Heading D --------- ``` HTML before make_read_more_link(): ``` html

Example

...

Heading A

...

Heading B

Heading B.1

...

...

Heading B.2

  • ...
  • ...
  • ...

Heading C

Heading D

``` HTML after make_read_more_link(): ``` html

Example

...

Heading A

...

Heading B

Heading B.1

...

Read more...

...

Heading B.2

  • ...
  • ...
  • ...

Heading C

Heading D

``` Everything that follows the "Read more..." is too mush but I haven't found a way to remove this with PyQuery yet.

Adding `doc('p.readmorewrapper').parents().nextAll().remove()` seems to work (no problems on my blog). ``` python def make_read_more_link(body, docpath, docname): """ Create "read more" link if marker exists. """ doc = pyquery.PyQuery(body) link_p = ('

%s

' % (docpath + docname, UIStr.READ_MORE)) doc('div#more').replaceWith(link_p) doc('p.readmorewrapper').next_all().remove() doc('p.readmorewrapper').parents().nextAll().remove() return doc.html() ``` I've created a pull request.
Thanks a lot Christian for quickly figuring this out!
BTW, neat fix with parentrs().nextAll().remove()!

It is possible to do this manually if you have two folders `_images` and `_copy/_images_big/` and put full-scale images inside `_copy/_images_big/`.

And then use something like this:

```
.. figure:: /_images/blinking_led_small.jpg
  :width: 500px
  :alt: Blinking LED
  :align: center
  :target: ../../../_images_big/blinking_led.jpg

  Blinking LED
```

If you want an automated solution then you have to write a Sphinx extension that downscales the images automatically.

This does not belong in Tinkerer core. You can pull the extension itself to tinkerer-contrib and document the change needed to hook it up to the template. @moigagoo In my Atom feed extension, I get the last modified time of a post's .rst file using  `os.path.getmtime()`: https://github.com/sgillies/rutherford/blob/master/rutherford/__init__.py#L80. Published time as well as date would be good, I agree.

By design, Tinkerer does not save this kind of state (build time, first build etc.). The scenario is definitely valid, but I wouldn't add this kind of state tracking to Tinkerer core, as not everyone needs it and it adds a lot of complexity. This timestamp might also mean different things to different people (first build time, last build time, publish time etc.).

I have no issue with this being implemented as an extension (if anyone volunteers :)), but I wouldn't add this to the core logic.

This is caused by using an out-of-date translation template (.pot file). 

The included .po files are made from a template that was generated at Tinkerer version 0.4b in 2012. Some strings in the code have changed since then and thus the ones in the .po file are no longer valid and simply don't get used.

I have generated a new and up-to-date template in #69. Once that is merged in you can use the file in /tinkerer/ext/locale/tinkerer.pot as a template for the translation.

Note: A translation template (.pot) is just the same as a .po file, except the header is slightly different and no strings are translated in the .pot file.

Here are the steps I followed.
I installed tinkerer in my active virtualenv

```
pip install tinkerer
```

In my blog directory I did

```
tinker --setup
```

I edited the conf.py to my preference and then created a post and a page

```
tinker --post 'Hello World!'
tinker --page 'About'
tinker --build
```

The htmls were generated but the static files folders are empty. It seems the theme files are not loaded. I thought I missed a step and decided to remove everything and do it again. Result is still the same. You can see it [here](https://github.com/felixcheruiyot/felixcheruiyot.github.io). Visiting the [site](http://felixcheruiyot.github.io) does not load the theme.

Note: No errors flashed during building, post and page creation.

Other details:
- I am running Ubuntu 13, python 2.7. Tinkerer is installed in a virtialenv

_static directory seems to be there under blog/html. If you are hosting on github, make sure to have a `.nojekyll` file in your repository root, otherwise github tries to serve things through Jekyll. Tinkerer (Sphinx) is not compatible with Jekyll, specifically due to underscores at beginning of names. Jekyll has special meaning for those, which you don't want for Tinkerer static websites.

This is a good idea. 

The alternative I've used thus far is starting a simple http server from the root of the project, where `index.html` is located. I do that running a batch script (I'm mostly on Windows):

```
python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8888 &
```

@gisraptor could you elbaorate on the advantages of this pull request over this one-line script?

BTW, it appears the CI build fails, probably because you don't have permissions on the Travis server to start an http server instance. Please check the "failed" notice on the bottom of your pull request description.

@serra Here are a few of the advantages I see coming from this:
- Internalizing the server functionality gives Tinkerer a more <del>civilized reputation</del> polished presentation when compared with other blog hosting software (or at least keeps it on par with others)
- The command to run the server is easier to remember (although the batch/shell script couldn't be that hard)
- It makes testing/developing new themes easier
- Tinkerer ensures that I start the server from the base directory, same as almost everything else
- It can take multiple simultaneous requests due to the use of the ThreadingMixin from the SocketServer module

I took a look at the CI build failed notice on Travis. It appears it failed only in the Python2.6 environment, which I subsequently ran successfully on my local box. The Python2.7 and Python3 environments completed without a problem. I suspect the build box was still spinning up the server when the request for the page was issued and the request was not answered. I have introduced a time delay in the test to mitigate errors of this sort. If it continues I will be glad to look into it further.

Thanks for considering this change.

I don't quite understand why you would want to use an HTTP server to locally preview your blog. Tinkerer generates a static website so you can achieve the same just by opening index.html in your favorite browser. That is how I preview all posts and how I work on themes. Since it's all static, it can be served directly from the local file system. I don't see why you would need an HTTP server. What am I missing here?

@vladris I agree that viewing static HTML content works just fine without the HTTP server and it would seem to be overkill. The problem arises when a user would like to include any external Javascript components in their blog. Those components will not be loaded and cannot be previewed to see the full impact of the page, without serving them. Having a simple way to serve the blog locally would allow users the ability to use Javascript in their blogs. It would also allow the use of page scaffolding toolkits for the blog layout such as Bootstrap or HTML5 Boilerplate. Maybe I am trying to expand the initial intent of Tinkerer. If so, I would hope that you would consider my viewpoint. Thanks.

I've included some d3js charts with my blog that required serving the blog from behind an http server at design time. So I do see the use case, but I'm not sure if this should be a core feature of tinkerer. For me the one line script from above is sufficient.

I would like to understand the motivation for the development of Tinkerer. Would you mind helping me get a better picture of Tinkerer's direction? That will help me understand why this feature may not be desirable and give me some ideas on how to contribute in a more productive fashion. Thanks.

Sure. Tinkerer is meant to be a static blog file generator - think Octopress. The idea is you write your blog in RST format, you build it, and end up with a bunch of html files which you can host on places like BitBucket, GitHub or anywhere else for that matter. RST is great and Sphinx is an awesome tool but it was built for writing documentation not blogging. Tinkerer tries to close that gap by providing a set of extensions and tooling to allow blog building with the Sphinx engine.

Neither Sphinx nor Tinkerer have anything to do with the way you decide to serve the built files.

While I don't deny that it might be useful to quickly spin up a server to locally preview Tinkerer served over HTTP, I don't believe this should be part of the core translating-RST-into-a-blog functionality. You could definitely contribute this as an external tool that can serve the blog, but not part of Tinkerer core. You can either put it on PyPI or pull it to tinkerer-contrib repository, but I'd rather have it as a standalone.

Thanks for your interest in the project and I'm looking forward to seeing your future contributions!

@vladris I have attached a patch that uses Babel to format dates.

There are some issues, still:
1. Translations must be updated, because Babel uses a different formatting language than `.strftime`.  Should be easy though, since the mapping from `.strftime` to Babel's format is mostly straight-forward.
2. I left one instance of `strftime` around, in a strange function `split_date` in `utils.py`.  
3. I didn't check any test cases…

I can fix these, but I need your explanation and opinion.

1) I can either update all translations, but I don't think that the format still needs to be translatable with babel.  Babel provides generic formats for short and long dates, which represent the corresponding locale's standard way of formatting dates.  They differ a bit from what Tinker currently uses, especially with regards to the short format, but I don't think it is worth the hassle of keeping these translations around for this tiny bit of control.

If the date was given with generic formatters, we could just add a Jinja filter for `format_date`, and do all the formatting in the templates.

2) As said, the whole purpose of this function is strange to me.  It seems to be used in `Post` to parse dates given on the command line when creating posts, but I don't get the whole date handling in `Post`.  Imho the whole API is convoluted.

Why do you split the date into three parts in the `Post` class?  Why don't you just use `datetime.date`?  Why don't use parse the date given on the command line with a custom `argparse` `type`?

But anyway, this function uses a mostly language-agnostic date format (at least with regards to western languages), so it should be safe.  It'll break, though, should a user ever get the idea of giving a Japanese date on the command line…

3) I can try to add test cases, or run them, but since you said you'll test on Windows anyway, I didn't do so yet…

Tinkerer is a blogging engine, if you just want site generation, why not use Sphinx directly? That's pretty much what Sphinx does - it converts a bunch of RST files to a static website. For now, I am using this elegant shell workaround:

``` bash
tinker --build && mv blog/html/index.html blog/html/blog.html && \
cp blog/html/pages/projects.html blog/html/index.html && \

FYI, I'm looking into this. See ebbe133f71f1e27173d39c0ee3fb614066cc1b46. 

Current thinking: add `landing_page` setting in `conf.py`, eg. `landing_page = "about"` (you should also have an about page under `/pages`). As long as `landing_page` is set, the first page of aggregated posts will move from `index.html` to `page1.html` and `index.html` will instead become a redirect to the specified landing page.
Also added `first_page_title` setting to change the title of "Home" if needed. This should be enough to cover the landing page scenario. I will roll these out with the next release of Tinkerer.
Resolving this since new release has ability to override both landing page and "Home" string.

`blog/html` is removed and re-generated during each build. Tinkerer works with the assumption that you have your blog source files under source-control. You have 2 options: either have everything under source control (both sources and html - Tinkerer enables this by a root `index.html` file which just does a redirect to the `blog/html/index.html`) or you can keep the sources in some private repository and have a small script that copies your `blog/html` from the build location to the folder you want to push to github.

For date formatting, Tinkerer uses Python's strftime. I believe that strftime gets the name from the OS locale, not the locale specified for Sphinx. This is how strftime works and I don't think I want to provide an alternative implementation. Can you please try changing your OS locale to a different language and check whether that changes the name of the months? It should...

So the problem can be solved by adding:

```
import locale
locale.setlocale(locale.LC_TIME, "de_DE")
language = "de"
```

to `conf.py`.

PS: This does not work:

```
[chris@thinkpad tinkerer.git]$ ls test
ls: cannot access test: No such file or directory
[chris@thinkpad tinkerer.git]$ LANG="de_DE" ls test
ls: Zugriff auf test nicht möglich: Datei oder Verzeichnis nicht gefunden
[chris@thinkpad tinkerer.git]$ LANG="de_DE" tinker -b
...
```

Hi Erhan, are you using a modified/old theme, if I look into `tinkerer/themes/boilerplate/rss.html` the title should be within a CDATA block: ``` {{ item.link }} {{ item.link }} <![CDATA[{{ item.title }}]]> {%- for category in item.categories %} {%- endfor %} {{ item.pubDate }} ``` But yours looks like : ``` http://blog.muhuk.com/2010/03/29/free-software-linux-days-2010.html http://blog.muhuk.com/2010/03/29/free-software-linux-days-2010.html Free Software & Linux Days 2010 ...]]> Mon, 29 Mar 2010 00:00:00 +0800 ``` CDATA is there for the description but missing for the title. If you add the CDATA block to your template it should hopefully work, I've done it at least for the thinkerbase and boilerplate theme some time ago.

**[concat(variables('{}VMNamePrefix'), copyIndex(variables('{}Offset')),'/cse', copyIndex(variables('{}Offset')))]** to

Most likely this is blocked by system pods.

`kube-proxy` and `kube-svc-redirect` pods are ignored, but your `kube-dns`, `heapster`, `tunnelfront` and `dashboard` pods might be spread among the 3 nodes.

I am not sure I understand what you mean.
If a node is `UNDERUTILIZED_DRAINABLE` it will be cordoned and drained, and on the next pass it will be `IDLE_UNSCHEDULABLE`. Idle because all the pods have been drained and unschedulable because the node is cordoned.

I probably didn't understand the issue you are talking about though.
my bad ... closing ... this was an oversight caused by the fact that there is a 1800 seconds default idle threshold, i double checked the logs this works fine.

I think the issue might be that the underutilized nodes are always in busy_list (because of the kube_proxy-*) so even in the second pass it goes back to UNDER_UTILIZED_DRAINABLE and does not get to IDLE_UNSCHEDULABLE for deletion ... i'll run some test cases to validate. in any case ... this is working both ways (in and out). please let me know if i can be of any help here ... i'm trying to work on new features like mixed cluster (windows / linux) ... and other stuff

Vary strange... But in fact with acs-engine from muster branch I have deploy 1.9.2 Kubernetes without any error messages...

So this error was caused by RBAC, which is enabled by default in acs-engine >= 0.12.0. The autoscaler wasn't authorized to query k8s api since it wasn't authenticated.
I have tested and pushed a fix on master so you can try it out as well.
The README was updated with instructions, but here is a summary of what you need to do:
Clone this repo, and fill `./helm-chart/values.yaml`.
You'll need to provide a `subscriptionId` as well now.
For clusters generated with acs-engine >= 0.12.0 you will also need to provide `etcdclientprivatekey` and `etcdserverprivatekey` and set `rbac.install` to true.

The chart will create a new service account for the autoscaler as well as all the necessary RBAC roles and bindings.

Let me know if this solves the issue on your side as well.

Sorry for the delay.
It's hard to say, I would need more logs to be able to tell, but basically a node in `undeschedulable` state means it has already been cordoned and drained.
The autoscaler will look at the number of spare agents, and it should never  cordon and drain a node if the number of available node is <= 2.
However once a node is cordoned and drained, the AS will delete it no matter the number of nodes available, which is what is happening here.
So the question is how did this node ended up cordoned in the first place?
Is it possible that you did a manual `kubectl cordon` on the node?
No, pretty sure I did not. The weird part is that is somehow fixed itself - now look like the autoscaler behave normally...
I'll close this issue then as I can't really take any action on it, but if the issue comes back feel free to let me know I'll reopen.

> `New capacity requested for pool devops: 3 agents (current capacity: 2 agents)`

The current pool size is `2` and the new requested size is `3`

> `Requested a new deployment with unchanged pool sizes, skipping.`

This means that while there currently are only 2 nodes in the pool, the autoscaler already created a deployment with 3 nodes in the `devops` pool. So most likely the deployment is still going on so the autoscaler does not redeploy a second time. 

Deploying a new node should take somewhere between 4 to 12 minutes depending on the VM type.

Does this answer your question?

I assumed this is the reason thanks to this comment - https://github.com/wbuchwalter/Kubernetes-acs-engine-autoscaler/blob/master/autoscaler/deployments.py#L14.
I just thought it would be helpful to get more debug info about the data used in this condition (requested pool sizes and current pool sizes)

This is probably something for a separate issue but we had a case when the cluster was stuck in this state for several hours, and was only released when the stress got high enough to trigger the scaling of an additional node.

Yep, I understand what you mean.  

The issue is that from the autoscaler, there isn't really a way to know if the VM hasn't joined because it's still being created, or if there was an issue with kubectl or anything else, so there isn't any relevant info that could be logged here.
I could still do some periodic requests to azure to check the state of the deployment and report if it fails, but the deployment might report as successful while the VM has trouble joining the kubernetes cluster, so this would be an incomplete solution...

I thought of another way to solve this. Whenever the autoscaler reaches this state, we could use the azure cli to query the launch time of the instance launched by the deployment and at a certain point declare the instance as faulty, destroying it and launching a new one.
This might require implementing some new functionality but I think it's a good way of retrying failed scaling attempts.

I am in a similar scenario. The auto-scaler triggered a deployment, adding 2 nodes. However that deployment failed and the VMs did not join the cluster. How to get out of this log-jam? Should I delete the auto-scaler and re-deploy the auto-scaler again? (and clean up the failed deployment components on Azure)

Here is what I did.
1) Got the nodes that Kubernetes was reporting as "Ready"
2) In Azure, identified the VMs that did not join the cluster (or were in a failed state)
3) Removed those VMs, (and their NICs and OSDisks from storage accounts)
4) Deleted the auto-scaler
5) Re-installed the auto-scaler
Now it is working again. 

If auto-scaler resets itself to look at the initial deployment state, instead of the updated state (which might not be the current state anyway) - would that help?

Of course, "failed deployment states and their cleanup" - still needs to be addressed

@wbuchwalter It would be a really nice christmas present if this PR could be merged. I really need to  autoscale a customVnet cluster 👍
Yes.  I have tested it on my cluster for scaling in and out.

This is as designed.
`--spare-agents` instructs the AS to not scale-in under the specified number.
`--over-provision` instructs the AS to scale out an additional number of nodes when scaling is necessary (for example if you know that when your loads starts picking up, it grows very fast).

For example, I know of some other people using this autoscaler that are setting `--spare-agent` to `20`, But don't want the AS to scale to 20 when the number of VMs is under this number. Say an admin deleted most of the VMs because he knows there won't be any load during the week-end, but load might be highly unpredictable during the week and thus doesn't want the AS to make any decision by itself under 20 nodes.

I guess a good solution would be to add another parameter such as `--force-spare` to instruct the AS to make sure the cluster is always at least `--spare-agent`'s size.

For now a very dirty solution for you is to manually create as many pending pods as needed to force the AS to scale up to `--spare-agents`. The AS will then never go under this number unless you manually remove some VMs.

`kubernetes-acs-engine-autoscaler` is a node-level autoscaler. It will scale the nodes, not the pods.
If you want to scale based on some load, you should set up an [HPA](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/run-application/horizontal-pod-autoscale/) that will scale the pods based on some metrics (such as CPU usage).
If HPA scales more pods than can fit on your cluster `kubernetes-acs-engine-autoscaler` will detect it and scale the nodes so that everything can run.

If you already have configured HPA, then you should be able to see what's wrong by just doing `kubectl logs` on the autoscaler container.

1. `under-utilized-undrainable` means that the node is barely used (under 30% of it's capacity by default), but because the pods running there are not replicated anywhere else (such as system pods, or user pods that are not replicated) the autoscaler won't shut down this node to avoid service disruption.

2. Yes most likely. It seems you have barely anything running in your cluster, so even if you add more nodes, the autoscaler will see that they are not used and start deleting them.
If you don't want this nodes to be deleted you can use the `--spare-agents` flag and specify how many nodes per pool you want to keep at all time.

If you want to trigger a scale out, you can schedule a bunch of pods with a specific CPU requests. If you schedule enought of them, at some point your cluster won't be able to accomodate all of them and the autoscaler will start creating new nodes.

Thank you for the info! I am having difficulty with the --spare-agents feature and I'm not sure if it's a bug. If I set --spare-agents 1, will the autoscaler launch nodes to ensure 1 spare agent? Or does that flag only limit the termination of idle nodes? Here is my situation: In my cluster I have 2 pools: agentpool0 -- GPU pool agentpool1 -- CPU only pool I would like to scale the CPU and GPU nodes using different parameters (higher --spare-agents for CPU-only nodes), so I have run a CPU-only autoscaler like this: ```bash python main.py --ignore-pools 'agentpool0' --resource-group '' --spare-agents '1' -vvv ``` There are currently 0 CPU nodes in pool 1. Although there are no pending pods, I expect the autoscaler to launch a new CPU node to maintain the --spare-agents 1. Instead it takes no action. Here is the log output: ``` 2017-07-19 17:39:50,365 - autoscaler.cluster - INFO - ++++ Running Scaling Loop ++++++ 2017-07-19 17:39:53,759 - autoscaler.cluster - INFO - Pods to schedule: 0 2017-07-19 17:39:53,760 - autoscaler.cluster - INFO - ++++ Scaling Up Begins ++++++ 2017-07-19 17:39:53,760 - autoscaler.cluster - INFO - Nodes: 1 2017-07-19 17:39:53,760 - autoscaler.cluster - INFO - To schedule: 0 2017-07-19 17:39:53,760 - autoscaler.cluster - INFO - Pending pods: 0 2017-07-19 17:39:53,760 - autoscaler.cluster - INFO - ++++ Scaling Up Ends ++++++ 2017-07-19 17:39:53,760 - autoscaler.cluster - INFO - ++++ Maintenance Begins ++++++ 2017-07-19 17:39:53,760 - autoscaler.engine_scaler - INFO - ++++ Maintaining Nodes ++++++ 2017-07-19 17:39:53,760 - autoscaler.engine_scaler - DEBUG - max_nodes_to_drain for pool agentpool1 : -1 2017-07-19 17:39:53,760 - autoscaler.cluster - INFO - ++++ Maintenance Ends ++++++ ``` You can even see that max_nodes_to_drain (= `(pool.actual_capacity - self.spare_count)`) is -1, meaning it can at most terminate -1 nodes, but it doesn't actually launch +1 node.

`--spare-agents` instruct the autoscaler to never kill more than `(pool.actual_capacity - self.spare_count)` agents in the pool. So if you have `--spare-agents 1` and you currently have 4 agents in your pool, the AS will kill 3 agents at most.  
But the autoscaler will not launch new nodes to meet the `--spare-agents` count. If there is 0 agent in the pool that means the user killed the VM manunally (since the autoscaler couldn't have done it itself if you have `--spare-agents 1`), and so the autoscaler will not bypass the user choice on this by recreating the node.

If you schedule enough CPU loads on your cluster, first your existing GPU VMs will be filled, but then you will have some pending pods that won't fit on the GPU nodes. At this point the AS will trigger a scale up and recreate some CPU nodes.   
At this point if you kill all your pods, the AS will kill all existing CPU nodes but one.

https://github.com/wbuchwalter/Kubernetes-acs-engine-autoscaler/issues/40 would be an easier way to recover from this.

When you deployed your cluster you did something like:
`az group deployment create --name myDeployment ...`

If you don't remember which name you used, you can go in the Azure portal, in your resource group, under the deployment tab. This would be the name of the very first deployment.

If you didn't use the `-n` or `--name` flag when deploying the cluster then you don't need the `--acs-deployment` flag.

Assuming your deployment name is `myDeployment`, in `scaling-deployment.yaml` , you should have:
```yaml
[...]
   command:
            - python
            - main.py
            - --resource-group 
            - <your-group-name>
            - --acs-deployment
            - myDeployment
            - -vvv
[...]
```

Currently the autoscaler cannot work on clusters with a custom VNet. 

This is due to a limitation in ARM.  
In order to scale up, the autoscaler has to remove the NSG from the template before redeploying to avoid services interruption in the kubernetes cluster (see https://github.com/Azure/acs-engine/issues/979for more infos).  

But when you deploy a k8s cluster with a custom VNET, the NIC of each VM directly references the NSG, and so this NSG needs to be present in the template, which is not possible as explained above.

I will check if I can find a way to circumvent this, suggestions are welcome :)


Regarding the helm chart, the current version is deprecated, I have a PR opened since a while here: https://github.com/kubernetes/charts/pull/1408 hopefully it will get merged soon. I will probably duplicate the chart in this repo as well, so we can have an up-to-date version at any time.

Hi All,

I got this working with the following steps:

1.	Created a resource group
2.	Created a VNET in the resource group
3.	Created a NSG in the resource group with the inbound allow rules for 443 and 22
4.	Generated the template using acs-engine
5.	Deleted the NSG resource from the template.
6.	Modified the NSG variables to reflect the one created from the Portal.
7.	Modified the NSG ID to reflect the one created from the portal.
8.	Deployed the template successfully.
9.	Deployed the autoscaler
10.	Deployed a RC and modified to increase the pods.
11.	Correspondingly the autoscaler scales out the agent nodes.
12.	Now the autoscaler is successfully scaling in/out the agent nodes without any error.

The idea is to remove the NSG from the template and create it separately and then associate with the agent and master nodes.
This solution is verifed, I received the same setup from MS this afternoon, and it works fine! Great Job! @sprab

I got another work around that is similar to @sprab 

1. Created a resource group
2. Created a VNET in the resource group
3. Generate ARM template and parameters using ACS Engine
4. Separate the ARM template into 2 parts (resource NSG, resource other than NSG)
5. Deploy the resource NSG
6. Deploy the other resource (remove "dependsOn: [“[variables(‘nsgID’)]“] ")
7. Update route table for subnet

The reason to do this is to get around the ARM issue (or bug?) for requiring NSG dependsOn exists in the ARM template (without check the existence in the resources group)

However, i think removing "dependsOn: [“[variables(‘nsgID’)]“] " in the template generated in the Autoscaler's scale out process would be a better solution.  I am wondering if it could be done.

The MS team and I deployed the arn, by removing all the nsg entries and the k8s cluster was working limitedly, you couldn't expose anything and the control manager pod crashed when you did. But, the autoscaler worked and you could deploy pods and such... just couldn't expose them. 

@sprab  solution is simple, you just have to change 5 lines of code for it to work... We deploy and autoscaler cluster in under 10 mins. the autoscaling is nice too as it seems to break the node deployments into groups, which take about 4 mins to deploy...

> However, i think removing "dependsOn: [“[variables(‘nsgID’)]“] " in the template generated in the Autoscaler's scale out process would be a better solution. I am wondering if it could be done.

Problem solved.

I had used something like `echo "C89EB391-784B-46A2-A0C6-F81515300437" | base64` to encode `azure-sp-app-id`, `azure-sp-secret` and `azure-sp-tenant-id`.  This adds a newline character.

Instead, using `echo -n "C89EB391-784B-46A2-A0C6-F81515300437" | base64` omits the newline character and correctly encodes the secret.

It might be worthwhile to add a hint in the instructions about correctly base64-encoding the secrets.

BTW: The cluster is hosted in westeurope.

You can modify `acs-engine-autoscaler/templates/deployment.yaml` and add the debug flag under `command` like so:
```yaml
[...]
 command:
     - python
     - main.py
     - --debug
     - --resource-group
[...]
```

Fixed in #15

+1, this would be great for our use case!

Our use case is we run JupyterHub (https://github.com/jupyterhub/jupyterhub) for a large dynamic classroom, where our node needs vary from 1 - ~60-70 over the course of every week. Each student gets a pod, and we can't kill or reschedule it - it loses their in-memory state, which is important. For our autoscaler, we'd ideally:

To scale down:
1. delete empty nodes if any
2. cordon off nodes that have low utilization

To scale up:
1. Uncordon any nodes first (only if they were cordoned off by the autoscaler tho!)
2. Add new nodes.

The reason cordoning is important is because k8s by default spreads out pods across many nodes, and we often get to a situation where nodes have only one pod running on them - so we can't kill them. Before that pod dies (when the student logs out), another pod is scheduled there - continuing this pattern. So if we could cordon off nodes first, that'll improve our effectiveness a lot.

We implemented all of this in a custom autoscaler ourselves for last semester on GKE - https://github.com/data-8/autoscaler. There's some azure support there, but I don't think that works with acs-engine! I hope we can switch to using this one instead of our hand-rolled one tho :)

However I found out that a custom formatter has access to more information. Look at the file [customFormatter.js](https://github.com/wbuchwalter/tslint-loader/blob/master/formatters/customFormatter.js) and prepend `failure.fileName` to `positionTuple`. To include a custom formatter you have to configure the formatter directory and the name of the new formatter.

Took some trial-and-error to get it right.

Options:
```
{
    formatter: 'michael',
    formattersDirectory: 'tslint-formatters'
}
```

I created the file `tslint-formatters/michaelFormatter.js` and copied/pasted the contents of customFormatter.js linked above. I made the one tweak @almondtools mentioned. No need to change the Formatter name in the file.

@blacksonic I think you may have annotated an old commit.  That `options` object is getting recreated every time a new module runs through the loader (via [these lines](https://github.com/wbuchwalter/tslint-loader/blob/c2f69d21c1ba7da4f02bc927ce185ca816dda41d/index.js#L24-L27)).  We can't store the `program` on the `options` object because it get's discarded.  Instead, I decided to store it on the `webpackInstance.options`, which is the same for the life of the process, and represents the original passed in options.  It is stored as `tsconfigProgram`.

Just giving anyone a heads up.  I wrote this pull, but I'm no longer using `tslint-loader`.

I have moved to [fork-ts-checker-webpack-plugin](https://www.npmjs.com/package/fork-ts-checker-webpack-plugin).  It runs TypeScript typechecking and optionally tslint in a secondary node process that does not affect the Webpack build process.

[ts-loader](https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-loader#faster-builds) now recommends this setup.  Setting the `happyPack` flag (derived from also using the [happypack loader](https://github.com/amireh/happypack)) it performs transpilation only (`transpileOnly`), while fork-ts-checker is performing the typechecking & linting.  That and the addition of [cache-loader](https://github.com/webpack-contrib/cache-loader) & [thread-loader](https://github.com/webpack-contrib/thread-loader) (which is inter-changable with happypack), it has now immensely improved performance over the awesome-typescript-loader.

[Example of the suggested setup](https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-loader/blob/master/examples/react-babel-karma-gulp-thread-loader/webpack.config.base.js)

Using [TSLint Language Service](https://github.com/angelozerr/tslint-language-service) in VSCode, I figure why `ts-loader` (or other TS loader) doesn't include the plugin in the Compiler. That would mean that, in a way, tslint would run together within the compiler instead of using a separate loader and passing all result all over again from one loader to another.

Of course, by default, TS plugins get ignored during compilation. However, there is a workaround to make them work as part of the compiler. Advantage of this? Messages of tslint are part of the compiler diagnostics and tslint is run at the same time while the file is being transpiled (and type checking as well).

The problem with `ts-loader` is that Type Checking doesn't work with HappyPack or `thread-loader` which instead increases build time.
So I started to work on an experiment and finally decided to write a TS loader, with those ideas in mind, that works with HappyPack/`thread-loader` (including Type Checking) and runs tslint within the Compiler as a TS Language Service Plugin...
https://github.com/eddyw/owlpkg-typescript-loader

It works in my projects. However, it may still need some work. Part of the ideas where also taken from this thread and others.
