@mtraynham you are right that this would work for a single run webpack build, but webpacks ``--watch`` flag is an essential feature and should be supported by all loaders out of the box. But I guess your proposal would work.

Also, during my own tslint performance testing I found out that creating the ``Program`` object isn't that expensive (unless it is re-created for every single file of course, which only makes sense in a watch mode).

Here is a comparison between running tslint on our codebase directly and using tslint-loader:

webpack without tslint-loader (includes assets, less, etc): ~30 secs
webpack with tslint-loader and type checking enabled: ~80 secs
tslint CLI, with typechecking: ~6 secs

Using tslint-loader with type checking takes an additional 50 seconds for our webpack build to complete. But using tslint directly from the CLI instead takes only around 6 seconds.

So the performance issues people are reporting here aren't really tslint or typechecking related. As I see it the problem must be either in tslint-loader or webpack itself.

I wrote my own tslint-watcher based on the example I posted in a comment above. It works fine and is super fast. Though it would be best to look into tslint-loader/webpack and try to fix any problems there, I just don't have enough time to do that.

Looks we need to teach tslint-loader 2 things:

1. cache program (already done here: https://github.com/wbuchwalter/tslint-loader/pull/78)
2. re-create program on watch event - as far as I understand this can be done with webpack [compiler plugin](https://webpack.js.org/api/plugins/compiler/)

Okay, started to debug and I found the following:
The rule configuration going into the `convertRuleOptions` function in `tslint/lib/configuration: line 355` is an object literal, and you are trying to do a forEach on an object literal which is not a native function of Object.
So either use the Object.keys() and iterate over the keys or add Lodash forEach to iterate over this object.
I am happy to make a pull request?
The raw configuration object needs to be transformed in a way that `findConfigurationFile` works.
Can you show me how? I am just using the tslint-loader, upgraded to a newer version of tslint, tslint-loader and webpack. And since that upgrade I got this issue.
For Tslint 5 the raw configuration needs to be transformed with `parseConfigFile`. Fixed in version 3.5.3
I can confirm it solves the problem. Thank you.

There is something wrong with the code, it had a stack trace with the error.

```
./test/app/engine.ts
(Emitted value instead of an instance of Error) [8, 1]: Calls to 'console.log' are not allowed.

NonErrorEmittedError: (Emitted value instead of an instance of Error) [8, 1]: Calls to 'console.log' are not allowed.

    at emitError (/home/travis/build/wbuchwalter/tslint-loader/node_modules/webpack/lib/NormalModule.js:119:14)
    at report (/home/travis/build/wbuchwalter/tslint-loader/index.js:67:3)
    at lint (/home/travis/build/wbuchwalter/tslint-loader/index.js:62:3)
    at Object.module.exports (/home/travis/build/wbuchwalter/tslint-loader/index.js:125:3)
```

This is failing because webpack is expecting an `Error` instance to be passed to `emitError()`/ `emitWarning()`: see https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/master/lib/NormalModule.js#L112-L121
I think the correct solution may be to actually to patch the loader's code itself and just create a new error from the `result.output` in `report()`.

Hello, webpack give me the same error.

Including only your application code, or excluding `node_modules` for this loader will fix/workaround the issue. This does look like a bug, but to be fair, linting 3rd party Typescript is a bad idea as those libraries are very likely to have different linting rules from your own project.

``` javascript
{
  test: /\.ts$/,
  enforce: 'pre',
  loader: 'tslint-loader',
  include: path.resolve(__dirname, 'src')
}
```

**OR**

``` javascript
{
  test: /\.ts$/,
  enforce: 'pre',
  loader: 'tslint-loader',
  exclude: path.resolve(__dirname, 'node_modules')
}
```

@blacksonic , actually, our master will stay stable as long as stable version of peerDependency of tslint is chosen by user.
Starting from npm3 peerDependencies will not be installed automatically, so its up to user to install the version of tslint he wants. If he wants stability, he should install tslint v4, if he wants to try latest version he can install tslint@dev.

"As long as"... we can stay stable for sure if we introduce a new branch. Is it a big effort?
Most people want to stick with stable versions.

Otherwise with this philosophy every peerDependency should be marked with ```*-dev``` and I don't see it in many places, guess why? On dev branches breaking changes come and go and the author want to ensure that the package on the main branch stays stable always.

> Most people want to stick with stable versions.

They do it by installing stable versions of libraries, it is completely choice of end user.

If you choose separate beach (as tslint do for typescript), you should keep it up to date with master branch.

Pull request #51 closes this one.

Airbnb styleguide includes a lot of rules related with JSX, React and other stuff which is not used here.
In #51 basic ESLint support has been added. I think we can have this as starting point in any case.
Why not use typescript and tslint?
That will require additional transpilation step, which we think is overhead for relatively small amount of code we currently have

True, an additional step, but as the code grows you have added error checks done by typescript. I wouldn't think so much as typescript having to traspile the code. I like to think more of typescript as as additional error checker. Also, the transpilation doesn't take long.

I don't think the code here will grow much. This is the loader for webpack. It does not aim to do complex things. 
I personally use Typescript now in one of mine projects and find it extremely useful for refactoring code. But my code is approx. 50 times longer than the code of this loader, and I don't think we'll gain big benefits from Typescript here. 
Another downside of typescript is that after introducing it you'll bring in remap-Istanbul for correct code coverage, which is not actively maintained and has several nasty issues.

Thanks @AiSatan
So as I know, it is possible, but it is way too much work to do it.

Once an Assembly got loaded into an AppDomain, it cannot be unload, but it can be overloaded and there are some ways to change code business logics on the fly.
But to do that, the program you need to either hijack the process or modify some binaries, which is not much better than the current approach.

Data is, for sure, hard to get.
Depends on the method you choose, there are multiple options (and none of them is easy).

- If you plan to score a scene and apply things like reinforcement learning, you can just collect the data on the fly.
- If you wants to apply things like deep learning, you probably cannot use this project to collect data. You might need to get the dataset(s) first and check if they are compatible with this project.
- I also heard that someone use third-party software to save replays and programmatically convert to something compatible with this project, but I don't know which software.

I'll close this as this is beyond the scope of the project.

Hello @AiSatan, thank you for the clarifications. I have some questions regarding the DLLs:
- why aren't they included in the github source code?
- where do they come from?

My current understanding is that they're decompiled game files -> extended with hearthrock's logic -> recompiled. Is this correct? I'm asking because I would like to find out more about the capabilities of the bot engine. Please let me know if there are some resources where I can learn more about this (I tried reading through the issues but the information is kind of fragmented).

Thank you.

Hi, @v-secure 

> why aren't they included in the github source code?

I believe it's because dlls is not "source code" and it's easier to deliver/update through nuget.

> where do they come from?

this dlls from "~\Blizzard\Hearthstone\Hearthstone_Data\Managed", you can find them and use instead of nuget, but 'cause they (blizzard) start encrypt Assembly-CSharp.dll (#31), you'll need this code to decrypt it:

https://gist.github.com/yangyuan/14444ccbc08517f64b31cf24165fccf2

> My current understanding is that they're decompiled game files -> extended with hearthrock's logic -> recompiled. Is this correct?

I think you are right, but to be clear:

1. decrypt Assembly-CSharp.dll
2. patch Assembly-CSharp.dll with this code (it'll be add Hearthrock.dll to references, and call it before/after some methods):
https://github.com/yangyuan/hearthrock/blob/master/src/Hearthrock.Client/Hacking/MonoCecilExtensions.cs
4. replace original Assembly-CSharp.dll with patched version

well, bot engine can do anything that Assembly-CSharp.dll contain, if you need something new, for example, "bool IsMinionFrozen", you can easily add this here: https://github.com/yangyuan/hearthrock/blob/master/src/Hearthrock/Pegasus/Internal/RockPegasusSnapshotHelper.cs and re-patch Assembly-CSharp.dll

I think, best way to learn (if you don't work for blizzard, I believe that they have some manual) it's use engine's source code: https://github.com/yangyuan/hearthrock/tree/master/src/Hearthrock

I also updated my Fork

https://github.com/AiSatan/hearthrock

The different here, that I use my own nuget https://www.nuget.org/packages/Hearthrock.RedStone 

you can use my Fork, or just replace nuget in this project with mine and update pegasus.json file (https://github.com/AiSatan/hearthrock/blob/master/src/Hearthrock.Client/pegasus.json):

`﻿{ "checksum": "4137629A103C800246890911106F97412582FE8B", "version": "13.0.3.28329" }`

Please, check both repositories if you'll looking for new version

                raw_data = self.rfile.read(content_length)
                json_data = json.loads(raw_data)

                if self.path == "/trace":
                    ret = _trace.trace(json_data)
                elif self.path == "/mulligan":
                    ret = _bot.get_mulligan_action(json_data)
                elif self.path == "/play":
                    ret = _bot.get_play_action(json_data)
```

it is just json that came from post

1. in hearthstone the rock module send post request to your server-bot
2. your server got the post request and extract "post body"-json
3. your server-bot make decision and return answer as json
4. hearthstone-rock module make the decision

you can look to scene in this file for knowledge what it really have

I have exactly the same problem,
I looked in the debugger, and saw that both click method work as usual
sometimes, in the one game, it's can work one time(no matter first or not) then not work right after it

> @lanhin Said that this is caused by: "playing the battlecry" is a targeted action [cleric, minion], but once it is placed (and not yet battlecried), it becomes a different PlayOption halfway through, similar to that of an attack.

After the bot give `[cleric, minion]`, the engine should click/drop `cleric`, then `minion`. And during this time, the engine will not check `PlayOption`.

> 4. Not click who it was told to target with it

I think the problem is the 4th step. I believe that the bot tried to do that but failed.

By default, the delay between actions is 1 sec. And if the state is `RockPegasusGameState.Blocking`, also delay 1 sec. There might be some special cases when the state should be RockPegasusGameState.Blocking but it isn't. Thus the game tried to click the target in a bad time and failed.

One way to debug is to increase the delays to see if the problem is gone. Another way is to trace RockEngineAction.Apply() to make sure the engine does try to click the target.

@AiSatan Great job.

The Assembly-CSharp.dll in Hearthstone+PC+v10.0+MixMod.zip has some corrupted data in the header. (To be specific, in optional PE header)
The Assembly-CSharp.dll you provided has malformed data between 0x200 to 0x400. Which also falls in the range of optional PE header.

The original Assembly-CSharp.dll actually doesn't encrypt the data between 0x200 to 0x400. and it contains the information of reloc section.

So I suspect that there are some data in optional PE header which brings the trouble. The hearthstone corrupt that data during decryption (and magically solved the problem).

@AiSatan 
They just updated the client to 10.2. I use the Hexden to check the decompiled dll in the memory, it looks like they have fixed the issue (malformed data between 0x200 to 0x400). Instead, they choose not to decompile the data between 0x700200 and 0x700C00, which belongs to .sdata section.

I think they have improved their decrypt code. I tried to do that same thing in my decryption code (ignore .sdata) and it works.

I will update hearthrock as long as the Nuget package today. Thank you very much for your help.

First I want to emphasize that the purpose of this project is AI researching (and not include Turing test).
So we don't need to make the bots human-like. And personally, I prefer we don't do that because doing that might jeopardize this project (someone might abuse this project).

But I respect all recommendations, so I will investigate the possibilities but with lower priority.

About the details...
**wait or pause** it's easy to let bots control the speed of actions and the intervals between the actions.  I can add few parameters in the actions returned by bots.
**hovering** it could be implemented by a new type of action. 
**chat** SAA, but chatting should also be available during opponent's turn, need much more work.

I will take a look whether they are available in game states.
If yes, I will include them in next release.

Max resources and turn number has been added #21.
About deck id or cards in the deck... so far I haven't found a way to get them from GameState.

The code AiSatan posted is a good example to parse candidate play actions.

**Parsing the card data**
Hearthrock does not provide card database, but it provides CardId of objects.
https://github.com/yangyuan/hearthrock/blob/master/src/Hearthrock.Contracts/IRockObject.cs
You can find card information via any card database on the internet with that CardId.

**Thinking about a good move**
This is a big topic.
Hearthstone is complex enough and I believe there is no existing method which can apply perfectly on Hearthstone.
I tried to apply simple minimax algorithm, it sort of works if I can predict the result of actions.
I am doing research on predicting the result of actions with historical data (use machine learning), still on going.

I will be glad to help you!
Only problem that I see - new cards, it's crash all learning, because the "meta" will change

I found some interesting stuff in memory, may we can extract it 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2905049/27636769-c7288288-5c15-11e7-9576-31753f7f8c15.png)

The stuff the left window are parsed dotNET assembly metadata, it should be there because dotNet need them to be there to run the code.

So your screenshot proves that the Assembly-CSharp.dll still contains dotNet assembly, not native code.
Theoretically, we can extract that and generate the corresponding DLL. But I don't think it's a good idea.
First, it's hard. Second, it needs many manual works. Third, even if we succeed, we still need to find a way to inject our code to their DLL.
I am trying to find out how they load the assembly, it would be better if we use the same way to decrypt the assembly.

It seems that they modified the PE signature in the DLL, and they encrypted the text (assembly) data.

`00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00` got encrypted to `0D B7 E7 D6 FF 5A 81 57 0D B7 E7 D6 FF 5A 81 57`
You can see the repeating `0D B7 E7 D6 FF 5A 81 57`, but `5A 20 00 00 00 00 00 00` got encrypted to `D5 03 82 B6 1A 78 D8 74`
So maybe it's a 64bit padding AES...

According to the PE structure meta, the file should end at address 0x609200.
And the content after address 0x609200 looks abnormal, maybe the AES key is there.

```
69 E0 D3 AA 36 D1 29 B0 13 E1 3A 30 A5 7A F0 B1
3C 38 A4 68 D6 20 0A 2E B6 2D 94 38 DC 46 31 23
EB C7 A6 41 5E 46 6E BD 15 30 D9 93 12 61 E2 E5
FC 6E 64 26 C2 1F 2C AA 38 00 00 00 01
```

it could mean:
There is 1 block: `00 00 00 01`
Size 0x38: `38`
Block data:
```
69 E0 D3 AA 36 D1 29 B0 13 E1 3A 30 A5 7A F0 B1
3C 38 A4 68 D6 20 0A 2E B6 2D 94 38 DC 46 31 23
EB C7 A6 41 5E 46 6E BD 15 30 D9 93 12 61 E2 E5
FC 6E 64 26 C2 1F 2C AA
```

It's un-indexed extra data, so it makes sense being put there reversely.

Can't believe I'm still able to do hacking...
can you mby upload an old version of the Assembly-CSharp.dll ? than i will also take a look at it too.

I think about some hook on hs Assembly.Load methods, may we will find something.

I have attached old version as .zip

[Assembly-CSharp.zip](https://github.com/yangyuan/hearthrock/files/1124091/Assembly-CSharp.zip)

The assembly-csharp.dll from the mac version doesn't seem to be encrypted at all (I can at least open and edit it using dnSpy)
![bildschirmfoto 2017-07-05 um 11 49 00](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5159436/27859187-35abd388-6178-11e7-8903-3264e1440cc7.png)

Update: Mac version of Assembly-CSharp.dll does work on Windows.
They reference different native DLLs.

Trying alternative solutions.

BTW I think the decryption happens before Assembly.Load.
First, it's hard to hook Assembly.Load, but it's easier to hook the Windows API "LoadLibrary".
Second, they didn't encrypt Mac version, which may mean that they are using a technology only available in Windows.

And also I realized that normally the minimum block length for AES should be 128 bit.
So maybe it's not AES

I think it might be blowfish.
First, it supports 64 bits block.
Second, it supports up to 0x38 bytes key... exactly the length of the extra block in the end of the file.

I noticed hearthstone.exe embedded the OpenSSL static lib, so probably they are using an encryption available in OpenSSL, and blowfish is there.

I'm setting up an environment to test this hypothesis...

Well, I think I can fix discover and adapt, it's work for me now, but I need more test and I am not sure how to implement it better

**About Choice Cards**

The suboptions are available. But sometimes bot might be stuck in a state that:

>  The parent card has been chosen and the sub cards cannot be chosen. And the bot is trying to choose other cards instead of sub cards.

This might happen due to some client/human issues. Right now I don't think its an issue.

**About Discover/Adapt Cards**

IDK why, but in the code Blizzard choose to make Discover/Adapt not an "Option", instead, they make it a separated field "Choices" in GameState class. I didn't notice that.

Maybe because the behavior of Discover/Adapt and Mulligan are too similar so they decided to share the design.

I've changed the code and doing some final test, probably will push the commit soon.

But, I'm assuming all the Discover/Adapt cards will only ask for choosing one option, is there any exceptions?

**ChoiceCardMgr**

I don't think this is a good direction. ChoiceCardMgr is a UI class. I believe Blizzard must be following the basic design practices and keep "State" and "UI" separated. ChoiceCardMgr probably has all the information we need but they might change that frequently.

Hi!

`fvim` is compatible with `nvr`, just `pip install neovim-remote` and you'll be able to use the command within the neovim terminal.
Outside the terminal, `nvr` doesn't know how to communicate with the server, so you'll have to specify a server address for nvim -- consult `nvr` manual for more info.

Also, you can use `fvim --fvr` option to connect to a FVim daemon (started with `fvim --daemon`) -- it's a session manager which also accepts remote editing commands.

Thanks @yatli. The `nvr` way does no suite my needs.

This is what I did using fvim:
```
fvim --daemon
fvim --fvr new test.sh
```

According to the documentation of fvim, I need a session id to connect to use `--fvr attach`. But I did not find a way to get it. I can only open a new fvim gui using `--fvr new`. Is it possible to send one certain file to an existing opening fvim gui using `--fvr attach FILE`?

```
    --fvr id [FILES...]         Connects to a FVR server.
    --fvr a[ttach] [FILES...]    - id: an integer session id to connect
    --fvr n[ew] [args...]        - attach: attach to the first available session 
                                 - new: create a new session with args passed to
                                   NeoVim.
```

hey you figured out, nice :D

Simply click "X" and close the fvim instance -- in FVR mode it will detach, not exit.
You can also use the ex command `:FVimDetach`

Another trick is that if you have a remote server running fvim daemon, you can use `fvim --ssh target-machine --fvr attach` -- works like screen or tmux attach (won't be able to edit local files obviously).

I recently changed the osx launcher (https://github.com/yatli/fvim/blob/master/lib/fvim-osx-launcher) behavior, so that:

1. It looks for the user's default shell
2. It uses the default shell as a login shell, run `/usr/bin/env` to extract the environment variables
3. It creates an isolated environment from the extracted info, and launches FVim.

You can check for logs in the Console app. Search for events that start with "FVim:", it will print the captured PATH var so you can inspect what's wrong with it. Also check `SHELL` variable to see if it's your default shell -- and other variables to see if your default rc file is sourced.

Another gotcha is that the launcher may not be able to extract the environment from an interactive session. So if you have this at the beginning of your rc:

```bash
# If not running interactively, don't do anything
[ -z "$PS1" ] && return
```

Everything afterwards will not be sourced.

Hi @ArkjuniorK !

Background composition only works for KDE and its derivatives. GNOME3 (and Cinnamon etc.) do not support blur behind at the moment.

As a work around I have put this into my init.vim which seems to fix the issue:

```
    if exists('g:fvim_loaded')
        autocmd UIEnter * runtime! ginit.vim
    endif
```
Perhaps we want to replace this line's VimEnter with UIEnter?

https://github.com/yatli/fvim/blob/218651d0747d33e4e0cbbd6e549afa05d72b7318/model.fs#L641

I'll have to think about this. Why doesn't `VimEnter` trigger? That's the singleton event that comes to my mind, while `UIEnter` may be called multiple times when you attach multiple clients (did it a few times for pair programming.. it was fun)

@Murlocks fixed. The solution is to check `v:vim_did_enter` and if so, invoke ginit.vim directly.

I just realised that once FVim is launched its `$PATH` is what `eval /usr/libexec/path_helper -s` returns. The same happens if I source `/etc/profile` instead. This is a problem for users that have custom paths on their shell initialisation files, so I'll mark this as `WIP`. I guess  the solution is to remove the launcher entirely, but if I do that FVim doesn't start, I guess because it cannot find some libraries

`nvim` is not in the path.

That's the only place we call `Process.Start` :)

I think I have a clearer picture now. The problem with the PR is that although it correctly passes the `$PATH` to FVim and it starts successfully, FVim only uses it to launch `nvim` and then it doesn't keeps it around (i.e. although `:!/usr/libexec/path_helper -s` correctly reports my `$PATH`, `:echo $PATH` doesn't). The problem is the user loses access to any external binary (in my case I install things like FZF with the Nix package manager) and other useful environment variables. Previously it worked for some users because it sourced `/etc/profile` and `~/.bash_profile`, but failed for users of other shells.

So I think what the PR lacks is a way to get (probably in [`neovim.fs`](https://github.com/yatli/fvim/blob/83a779851ada77ea2857895a02843735793858c4/neovim.fs)):

1. The value of `$SHELL`
2. Use it to execute `env` (this will provide all the user environment variables, not only `$PATH`)
3. Parse the output and feed it to Neovim at launch

I got the idea [from goneovim](https://github.com/akiyosi/goneovim/blob/master/editor/editor.go#L374). I switch between both GUIs randomly and in my experience works quite well. If you agree with the description I'll try to implement it myself

Interesting findings, nice work!

Make sure to have platform-aware guards so that the code path is not picked for Windows.
Example:
```f#
let DefaultFont =
    if RuntimeInformation.IsOSPlatform(OSPlatform.Windows) then "Consolas"
    elif RuntimeInformation.IsOSPlatform(OSPlatform.Linux) then "Monospace"
    elif RuntimeInformation.IsOSPlatform(OSPlatform.OSX)   then "Menlo"
    else "Monospace"
```

The process env can be set with this: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.diagnostics.processstartinfo.environmentvariables?view=netframework-4.8

It does exist and I am currently using [this vim plugin](https://github.com/jeffkreeftmeijer/vim-numbertoggle) to set it up for me.  It is actually very simple:

```
augroup numbertoggle
  autocmd!
  autocmd BufEnter,FocusGained,InsertLeave,WinEnter * if &nu | set rnu   | endif
  autocmd BufLeave,FocusLost,InsertEnter,WinLeave   * if &nu | set nornu | endif
augroup END
```

When the focus is lost, FVim has to send an RPC message to nvim.

I think it is my fault. The `termguicolors` option is by default off.

In the `init.vim` file, I have checked if the `TERM` variable is set to `xterm-256color`  and then set the `termguicolors` option:

```
if $TERM == "xterm-256color"
    set termguicolors
endif
```

Inside neovim GUI front end, the `$TERM` variable is empty.  Nvim-qt may have some sort of settings that set the `termguicolors` option. But it also occurs to me that since fvim is also a GUI program, maybe it should set `termguicolors` by default, which makes sense to me.

I have opposite scenarios where termguicolors breaks highlighting.
A GUI is not a TUI so I think by definition, termguicolors should be irrelevant, because what it does is to force highlight-guifg and highlight-guibg when the terminal supports ISO-8613-3.
With a GUI, that should be supported without explicit settings.
But without setting `termguicolors` option explicitly inside `ginit.vim`, the color is apparently wrong. What is the reason?
I think it's because the colorscheme you're using is broken in notermguicolors?

That may be the reason since most of the color schemes today presume that we are using a terminal emulator that supports true colors. So if `termguicolors` option is not set, the color shown will be wrong.
I remember earlier (back when I haven't started the FVim project) that some colorschemes will use aggressive approximations when termguicolors is detected.

On my current colorschemes ( `let s:vsim_theme_name    = ['falcon', 'gruvbox', 'gruvbox', 'Tomorrow', 'Tomorrow-Night', 'Tomorrow-Night-Blue', 'pencil', 'pencil', 'colorzone', 'PaperColor', 'PaperColor']`
 ), setting {no,termguicolors} doesn't affect anything
@jdhao could this be related: https://github.com/equalsraf/neovim-qt/issues/219
I don't think it is related. That issue is about how to detect whether nvim-qt is started.

I've experienced incorrect color settings in `falcon` because it has `has('gui_running')` and in fvim it's always 0

So if in a colorscheme file:
```
if !has('gui_running')
  "do something with termguicolor
endif
```

The gruvbox_8 theme I use checks if `termguicolors` option is set or if `has('gui_running')` is true, as indicated by the code [here](https://github.com/lifepillar/vim-gruvbox8/blob/master/colors/gruvbox8.vim#L32). Without setting `termguicolors` option, the color will be wrong.

Yeah. I'd rather want `has('gui_running')` to be fixed instead of setting `termguicolors`.
Nevertheless, the current behavior is wrong. FVim reports neither a GUI, nor a terminal capable of showing GUI colors.

thanks for reporting the problem. looks like the first entry is triggered too eagerly.

Actually I think neovim doesn't use reverse colors to highlight. As you can see the background for the highlight changes based on the thing highlighted. Maybe I'm misunderstanding your comment, but I believe highlighting in vim is more complicated than a reverse color calculation.

# Suggestion about Linux support

An option is just leave it transparent, and let the compositor to build the blur effect...

(the x,y is the offset from window left-top corner to actual content left-top corner, it is only useful for client side shadow)
## For KDE
_KDE_NET_WM_BLUR_BEHIND_REGION (4 uint32 values) x, y, width, height
## For Deepin WM
_NET_WM_DEEPIN_BLUR_REGION_ROUNDED to (6 uint32 values) x, y, width, height, radius-x, radius-y
## For other compositor
I don't know, but it may not need to do anything
thanks @codehz! are these routines from a dynamic library, or some kind of settings?

@yatli low-level api: Xlib
reference: 
https://www.x.org/releases/X11R7.6/doc/libX11/specs/libX11/libX11.html
```
XChangeProperty(Display *display, Window w, Atom property, type, int format, int mode, unsigned char *data, int nelements);
```
which Atom property is from
```
Atom XInternAtom(Display *display, const char *atom_name, Bool only_if_exists);
```
but I think there some high level api...

PS: for testing, you can use those command in your shell to set properties to window
```bash
# KDE
xprop -f _KDE_NET_WM_BLUR_BEHIND_REGION 32c -set _KDE_NET_WM_BLUR_BEHIND_REGION '0,0,1920,1080'
# DeepinWM
xprop -f _NET_WM_DEEPIN_BLUR_REGION_ROUNDED 32c -set _NET_WM_DEEPIN_BLUR_REGION_ROUNDED '0,0,1920,1080,0,0'
```
Unfortunately, gnome 3 is not supported (but they may add blur support in GTK4 https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/GTK/Roadmap/GTK4)

If I want the blur behind region to fit the whole window, I have to actively track the resize events?

> If I want the blur behind region to fit the whole window, I have to actively track the resize events?

In fact, if you want to blur **the whole** window, you can just put a single 0 to _KDE_NET_WM_BLUR_BEHIND_REGION...
```
xprop -f _KDE_NET_WM_BLUR_BEHIND_REGION 32c -set _KDE_NET_WM_BLUR_BEHIND_REGION '0'
```

Actually I figured out why this was the case. I set all of my path variables via a powershell profile because I feel I have stronger control over the lifetime and contents of the path variable this way. However this means that when I run install, fvim doesn't know where nvim exists because its not on my system path. I think this could be fixed by making the shortcut pass the location of nvim manually instead of assuming a command called nvim exists.
So I think the ask here is that calling --setup should record the current location of nvim and use that in the shortcut instead of just whatever nvim command is available.
understood. thanks for trying out the very experimental stuff -- the setup process needs a lot of improvements! :)

Tracking: #103

can confirm for Win10 , emoji clips right boundary on most input conditions (but doesn't always clip) for __initial render__.

Example keying in order:
`😀  aa` clips slightly (there's 2 spaces there, 3 space is ok)
`😀a a` is ok
`😀aa` is not ok
`😀😀😀` is ok

Forcing it to redraw screen always ok, unless you start editing right of emoji again. (Btw @yatli how to do full redraw for debugging? Right now I just do `<C-f> <C-b>` )

Looks like it has to do with fvim waiting to see if the next 3 characters is some sequence for unicode or some other encoding, and creates a big boundary (treats 3 characters as 1) that clips into the emoji.

Looks like it does this for other characters too, just only in emojis you can visually see it...
`ȧaa` etc. will clip `ȧ` right boundary.
upstream issue: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/7151

+30.0 -> -10.0 = OK
+30.0 -> -30.0 = BAD

So even real values that are huge still ok, only really big ones that no one would do are bad. But probably need to confirm with someone with lower spec computer?

it's related to the rendering method: for each target span, first the background is drawn, and then the text is rendered on the background.

The text rendering may span into the next line, but when the next line draws, it is clipped.

Very interesting.
What I want to do is described in the comments in `RenderText`:
```F#
    //  h = [padding space 1] + above baseline | below baseline + [padding space 2]
```
I use `FontMetrics.Top` for "above baseline" and `Bottom` for "below baseline".
You can think of paddings as 1/2 leading space.
So, flipping items around we can calculate the padding, and the baseline.

But actually the equation simply does not hold in the clipping case -- here's some running data logged:

```
ui: h: 17.142857 bottom: 6.841290, top: -16.205219, total padding: -5.903652
```
Which means, (top+bottom) is actually bigger than what I measured as line height (???)

Ok I try to debug this... but don't know F# or Avalonia at all 😅
x +13 , y + 58
Seems consistent

PositionChanged event immediately triggers after MainWindow.xaml.fs initialization (this is where +13, +58 come from). Anyway I am not sure why, does not seem right for event to trigger so fast. Window initializes with correct values, but it happens so fast that by the time the window is rendered, you see the wrong values on screen.


So looks like this:
1. Load cfg , initialize Window -- OK
2. OnDataContextChanged trigger (from initialize?) -- OK
3. PositionChanged triggered (from ondata?) -- BAD
4. Window init finished, renders to screen and I see the bad position
then.....
few seconds later see another PositionChanged trigger (same bad position) but why? I still have not touched the window.

Could it be possible during load need to set Window.X,Y as PixelPoint? Looks like X,Y is set as int -> float and then converted at PositionChanged to PixelPoint? But again I'm not familiar with F# / avalonia.

thanks @nree! that's a comprehensive run!

I'm looking into this with the "Window Spy" utility from ahk.
`this.Position` correctly sets the screen coordinates in PIXELS.
`PositionChanged` events are also PIXELS, but always report offset'ed coordinates -- (12, 52) in my case
the fix is to measure the miscalculation on first event, and then compensate. works pretty well on my side. :)

Ok I think I see the problem... when a font is not found fvim defaults to some behavior like this instead of doing nothing & reporting font is not found. I think it is trying to load Arial or some fallback font. If you look at your screenshot it isn't Fira Code that's loaded.

if you do `:set guifont=FiraCode:h11` you will get this, because the font name is incorrect.

instead try `:set guifont=Fira\ Code:h11` and it should be ok.

Ok interesting apparently it only happens with first code light

Thanks for looking into it! I figured it out. Creating a package from a `PKGBUILD` file (`makepkg`) strips out static libs by default unless the following configuration is included:
```
options=('staticlibs')
```

implemented.
usage:
`:FVimFontLineHeight "height"`

`"height"` must be a string, and can be of these forms:
- number: "16.0" -- absolute
- signed number: "+1.0" "-1.0" -- additive
- "default" -- same as "+0.0"

Hi @yatli 
First of all, thanks for creating a neovim ui on the .Net platform. 😃 

I'm experiencing the same issue.
I've had a little dive into your code and traces while I've tried fvim key commands and I may be able to at least give some pointers.

Please take the following with a grain of salt since I'm neither an F# expert nor an Avalonia expert.

I'm using a German keyboard layout where ":" is on "SHIFT-." (so, SHIFT-period). The triggered input is ">".
When typing this key combination, "SHIFT-period" is exactly what is logged:

```
model: grid #1: OnInput: Key (Shift,OemPeriod)
```

So keystroke detection seems to work, right?
I've found that trace here: https://github.com/yatli/fvim/blob/master/model.fs#L398 so I attached a breakpoint.

The pressed key combination is then transformed here: https://github.com/yatli/fvim/blob/master/model.fs#L410

which seems to trigger the match here: https://github.com/yatli/fvim/blob/master/model.fs#L205
(sorry for all the links 😉 )

"SHIFT-period" is then explicitly transformed to nvim_input ">" here: https://github.com/yatli/fvim/blob/master/model.fs#L299

Of course, changing

```
        |  Key(HasFlag(KeyModifiers.Shift), Key.OemPeriod)            -> Normal ">"
```
to
```
        |  Key(HasFlag(KeyModifiers.Shift), Key.OemPeriod)            -> Normal ":"
```

"solves" the issue (for users of a German keyboard layout, therefore the air quotes 😃).

Thank you for the offer, yatli. However, I think you should rather pursue a general way of making sure that FVim is interacting with the "system keyboard", i.e. the layout set by the operating system, rather than either assuming a layout or interacting with some kind of "hardware layout" or some such. Although I have no knowledge of F# whatsoever, surely there must be a way to catch keys "as interpreted by the operating system"?

The issue isn't how a non-US keyboard layout works in ViM, but rather that keys are mapped differently in different languages. What we want is for FVim to get, that when I press, say, "shift + the second hardware key from the right-hand shift-key", it is mapped to ":". Whereas you would, on a US-keyboard, press a different hardware key for the same result (":"). 

It wouldn't help, I think, if we'd sit down and show you what it looks like, or how ViM behaves on non-US keyboards. ViM works the same way on all keyboards --- but different layouts have different hardware keys mapped to, say, ":". You need to catch pressed keys in the same manner as the OS does, not have FVim make an interpretation separate from the OS.

Thank you for the explanation @krissen !
And yeah.. That's the part I can't get my thinking through. Say every key has a virtual code, no matter what layout it is. Let's call it VK. Generally, I'd like the OS to provide the translation service to me, so I ask for `F = get_translation(layout)`, and, VK in, F(VK) out. Simple, right.

But getting modifiers involved fries my brain. Say there is a key that `F(VK)=TR` where TR is translated text, and CTRL is pressed. The way Neo/Vim process CTRL+key is that you send a string `<C-TR>` (C for control). But think about when TR=å, and we send through `<C-å>` -- how is that going to be understood as `<C-[>`?

I'd say you're still trying to figure it out the hard way --- but, entirely unfamiliar with Avalonia, perhaps that is the path you have to take.

Just to reiterate the point in my post above, using your recent example. It shouldn't matter what hardware keys are actually pressed, what matters is what the system interprets it as. You shouldn't, I'd think, have to bother yourself with how the user has his or her keys mapped, but what input the system tells you it has received. You shouldn't have to tackle all the different hardware keyboards and keyboard layouts there is. That is already tasked to the OS. 

Never mind if the user _presses_ hardware keys `<C-å>` or `<C-[>`, what matters is what it _means._ That interpretation is tasked to the OS, not to the individual applications (unless said applications are made with programming languages close to the hardware, not interfacing with the operating system). Hardware makes signal "keys `<Ctrl-Alt-8>` pressed" (yes, those are the keys I'd press on macOS, if I'd want `<CTRL+[>`); the OS interprets it: "ah, I see you want to express `<C-[>`" and forwards _not_ the hardware signal (`<C-A-8>`) _but the meaning_ (`<C-[>`); the listening application reads signal "input `<C-[>` received" and does what the user expects when said input is received.

I would think you'd be able to interface with the OS and from there receive the signal `<C-[>`. But perhaps Avalonia isn't there yet? Neither in the core or additional libraries? I don't know. Looking at some of the linked bug reports/feature requests, it looks like it might not be. It surprises me, but what do I know. 🤷‍♂️
Good timing. I'm staring at your comment for like 20 minutes :D

In a Neovim paradise, the OS just sends`<C-[>` and I would have nothing to complain about!
But in reality (read: Avalonia) that's not likely to happen.

In Avalonia there are two kinds of keyboard events -- text input events and key press events.
Normally a programmer will just work with "text input", which is already layout-translated (at least for Windows).
But here we're trying to forward everything that happens to the keyboard to Neovim -- and text input is not enough -- it doesn't even have the concept of modifier keys.
So what we get here is tuples of `Modifiers * KeyCode` where `KeyCode` is a layout-agnostic number (VK in my example) -- or rather say, "what key it should be if it's en-US".

Because Avalonia doesn't know about layouts, there's no way that the message will be translated, with keycode, or even the modifiers, being translated.
What's worse, the key codes we're looking at isn't OS-specific keys but normalized by Avalonia, so we cannot directly go back to an OS service.

So what you're asking is a good end result (Neovim paradise!) but there's a long way to go...

I guess Avalonia must have other great features going for it, as this sounds like an "early beta" type of issue. We're not talking about a Neovim paradise in my opinion, but merely basic functionality of a programming language; to be able to read input as it is intended. That is not Neovim specific. In _any_ application I'd input text in, I would expect to be able to write åäö, find characters like ]≈± where I'd expect them and so on. So, if I'd consider developing an application, I know for sure I won't choose Avalonia. 😂

My two cents: you should not beat your head against this particular wall. It sounds like it is Avalonia's issue. I'd advise you not to try and emulate all possible alternatives of keyboards and keyboard mappings; it would simply be too much work.

Possibly: leave the bug report open, and write a clear message in the README (referencing the issue here and in Avalonia's issue tracker): as long as Avalonia can't interpret the keyboard settings of the OS, FVim can only support standard US keyboards. Once this is fixed in Avalonia, things ought automagically work in FVim as well.

It's either that or ditch Avalonia. And as I'm guessing the latter wouldn't be an option, just keep doing what you like, and refer us non-US keyboard users to Avalonias bug tracker! It is their feature to add / bug to fix, not yours, by the sound of it.

Good point. I've updated the README to point to this issue, thanks!
I chose Avalonia because it's actually the best cross-platform UI framework for .NET, imo. It's like cutting through the hyperplane -- Choose wpf/uwp? No cross-platform. Choose Avalonia? Rough edges. Choose lower-level stuff like Skia/SDL/you-name-it? No advanced UI layouts and OS services. :)
Avalonia is moving forward so I take it the best of the three options above.
I will continuously work with them to see what's the best way to incorporate the layouts.

Your choice makes sense, cross-platform is always kind of a headache. I'm definitely surprised this is issue exists in Avalonia though, seems like a huge oversight to me.
But I agree, while FVim needs to have this fixed, it doesn't make sense to fix it here, when Avalonia is the real issue.

You did already send them a pull request with a potential fix though, what is preventing that from being merged?

The following does not add to the issue at hand, but if you're curious how the keyboard layouts look like, @yatli, [this](http://www.farah.cl/Keyboardery/A-Visual-Comparison-of-Different-National-Layouts/#sv) website gives a good visual representations of many keyboard layouts, as compared to en-US. (Link goes directly to the Swedish/Finnish one.) Do note that this is only for Windows/Linux; macOS differs, but only in details (like no `alt-gr`, the addition of `⌘` and slightly different placement/usage of some symbols, such as `[, ], {, }` for example.)

@cauer-feynsinn @pulcinello root cause resolved.

The neovim rejected our request to attach UI.
Reason: fvim is sending UI options from 0.4.x, not understood by 0.3.x neovim.

disabling the related options works around the problem.

There is 1 more thing which you can do:
You can redirect the traffic of AzureCP through Fiddler to inspect the actual traffic between AzureCP and AAD.
If you installed Fiddler locally and trusted its root certificate, you can do it per-web application by updating the web.config:

```xml
<system.net>
    <defaultProxy useDefaultCredentials="True">
        <proxy proxyaddress="http://localhost:8888" bypassonlocal="False" />
    </defaultProxy>
</system.net>
```

We have not had a chance to get around to using fiddler but we noticed the Web App related to the App Pool we used for testing had stop exhibiting issues with claiming tokens. However another Web App in the same environment still had the problem. Waiting to confirm results on some testing but logging into the App Pool account may clear this issue for us.

@Yvand To update the above on the instance with 19.0.20210211.1285 we have been able to clear the connectivity issues on a per web app basis by remoting into the server with their unique AppPool account. Sadly we are unsure on what exactly this is changing but its clearly having a positive effect for us.
@Charlie-Gunn do you mean that the issue was gone after opening a RDP session as the app pool account?
@Yvand Correct, after successfully RDPing to the Machine and logging in with the App Pool account, it successfully claims the token first time every time.

@Charlie-Gunn it makes me immediately think about [this problem](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/troubleshoot/administration/800703fa-illegal-operation-error).
You can take a look at the event viewer to check if you see such error, and I suggest you test the resolution in [method 2](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/troubleshoot/administration/800703fa-illegal-operation-error#method-2).

@Yvand Sorry about the delay in replying. We had almost the opposite to the issue in the link provided where instead the interactive login was solving the problem rather than creating one.

We believe one of the registry entries added in this case is resolving our connectivity issue but were unable to identify which one exactly made the difference.

So this is very likely the actual issue and the solution suggested should work

@Yvand I keep this in mind gong forward in the event the issue returns. So far we have had continued availability on the platforms this was completed on and I have been asked to avoid further changes on this matter for now. Thank you for your help on this!

@jaycallahan1973 AzureCP can work perfectly well with multiple web apps, IMO your problem is more a configuration issue between AAD and SP.
If you really want to rule out AzureCP you can remove it from the trust using this script:

```powershell
$t = Get-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer "SPTrust"
$t.GetType().GetField("m_ClaimProviderName","NonPublic,Instance").SetValue($t, $null)
$t.Update()
```

To add it back:

```powershell
$t = Get-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer "SPTrust"
$t.ClaimProviderName = "AzureCP"
$t.Update()
```

So I guess my question would be do you add 1 enterprise Application for the farm and if so do you do it like this?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/51999317/112565481-1ec3bb00-8dab-11eb-8e1e-56734744ad58.png)

or do you add different reply URLs for each [WebApp.](url)
I have tried several different ways, but never with the results I desire. 

And same for the SPTrustedIdentiyTokenIssuer.  I added several realms and the affect was the website redirecting to one of the others.  I may be making this harder than it is.

I was correct in the fact i was making this more complicated than it was.  Just added the URLs to the  Reply URL (Assertion Consumer Service URL), and then ran
$t = Get-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer "AzureAD"
 $t.UseWReplyParameter=$true
 $t.Update()

I made the mistake of putting the /_Trust/ on the end of the extra web applications.  Closing this out but thanks for the response.

Hi @aaclage, no, it cannot be removed.
Note that:
- Only the results that match the identity claim type don't have any prefix
- For the others, the text displayed, e.g. "Group", comes from the property `DisplayName` returned by `(Get-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer "TRUSTNAME").ClaimTypeInformation`

Hello @plantoschka, before explaining more, let me start by saying that this configuration is correct and you should keep it.

Regarding the display name, SharePoint gives a chance to claims providers (AzureCP) to set the display name **only** if the user is added for the very first time to the site collection. And no, it doesn't work to delete and re-add the user.

If the user is actually added for the 1st time (you may test in a new temp site collection), AzureCP will set the display name of the user (no matter if he is guest or not) based on this highlighted setting (in central admin > Security > AzureCP claim types configuration):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8788631/107968830-25dafa80-6faf-11eb-869d-8ec040029d3b.png)

In the screenshot above, it will be the Azure AD property 'DisplayName'

@vargasfe you can associate a claims provider with only 1 SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer.
Is your question related to having several SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer in a given web app, or a single SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer in multiple web apps ?

I want to have a SP farm with multiple web apps and each web app is connected to its unique SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer  (different from the ones used by the other web apps); and each SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer associated with its own, unique AzureCP.
Something like this:
Farm1 - WebAPP1 - SPTITI1 - AzureCP1 - AzureTenant1
Farm1 - WebAPP2 - SPTITI2 - AzureCP2 - AzureTenant2
Farm1 - WebAPP3 - SPTITI3 - AzureCP3 - AzureTenant3

This scenario is technically possible, but in practice I don't encourage you to go for something like this unless you really have to,
In fact I think it would be much easier to create 3 farms, each with it own AAD tenant, than going with this scenario,

With that said, you're right that there is a limitation: due to limitations in SharePoint API, AzureCP won't work if you set it with multiple SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer.
A possible solution is to create new custom claims providers that use AzureCP as a base class. It approach works fine but:
- It requires strong SharePoint dev skills to do this properly
- Usually I include a sample package with each build to show how to do it, but I just noticed it's missing in v18. I'll include it in v19, which I'll release soon

AzureCP should always set the value with the UPN, regardless of the display name which is different.
Can you check the SharePoint logs and filter on product/area "AzureCP" to see exactly how AzureCP creates the entities?
And you can configure this in AzureCP "Global configuration" page, and more deeply in the "Claim types configuration" page

When you say “ AzureCP should always set the value with the UPN”, which value are you referring to? The SP UserLogin value? When we change the AzureCP unique identifier to DisplayName, it is setting the UserLogin value to [claims header]|[DisplayName], and the SP Name value to [DisplayName]. When we set the AzureCP unique identifier to UPN, it is setting the SP UserLogin value to [claims header]|[UPN], and the SP Name value to [UPN].

That convert command is being run while the Trusted Token Issuer is still configured to use AzureAD though. We only change it to use AzureCP after the conversion (otherwise the Convert-SPWebApplication command fails).

The user identifier is always **the trailing part**: 
i:0e.t|aadtrust|**aaduser1@tenant.onmicrosoft.com**

With Azure AD, this identifier is always the userPrincipalName (for members) and you should really not change it.

Ah Ha! I figured it out in QA. I had to remove my old account that was still using the UPN as the displayname (using Remove-SPUser). THEN, when I added a new permission for my account, it used my correct display name.

Yvan,

I figured it out. It turns out that the SPTrustedIdentityTokeIssuer did not have the role claim.
Fixed it by adding the claim to the SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer and then adding the mapping.

$Name = "The name of you Trusted Identity Provider"
$ap=Get-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer $Name
$ap.ClaimTypes.Add("http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/role")  
$ap.Update() 

$map6 = New-SPClaimTypeMapping "http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/role" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "Role" –SameAsIncoming
$ap=Get-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer $Name
Add-SPClaimTypeMapping -Identity $map6 -TrustedIdentityTokenIssuer $ap

Thank you for updating the status of the issue!

AzureCP uses 17 [NuGet package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory 5.2.6](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory/5.2.6), which requires System.Net.Http (>= 4.3.4).
I think it's the cause of the issue, even though logs show that it tries to load System.Net.Http.dll V4.2.

Can you try the following script:

```powershell
[System.Reflection.Assembly]::Load("System.Net.Http, Version=4.2.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a")
```

Yvan,

When running:

[System.Reflection.Assembly]::Load("System.Net.Http, Version=4.2.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a")

I get:

"Could not load file or assembly 'System.Net.Http, Version=4.2.0.0,
Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a' or one of its dependencies. The system cannot find the file
specified."

However, when running:

[System.Reflection.Assembly]::Load("System.Net.Http, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a")

It finds and loads the proper assembly.  This is a SharePoint 2016 farm running on Windows 2016.  This is consistent across SharePoint 2016 farms.

Based on your previous comment https://github.com/Yvand/AzureCP/issues/104#issuecomment-729252011 you are already running with version 4.7.3620 (same as me)

I have a theory:
Both [Nito.AsyncEx](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Nito.AsyncEx/) (through a dependency on [System.Collections.Immutable](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Collections.Immutable/)) and [Microsoft.Graph.Core](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Graph.Core/1.22.0) (through a dependency on [System.Diagnostics.DiagnosticSource](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Diagnostics.DiagnosticSource/)) have a dependency on [System.Memory](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Memory/), but the subtlety is that I think one has it through .NET Standard 2.1 and the other through .NET Framework 4.6.1.
When restoring packages NuGet makes a choice, and it may be that (bad?) choice that is causing the issue.
I get this suspicion after reading [this article](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/net-standard), especially the little "2" note, as AzureCP currently targets .NET Framework 4.6.1...

Well, I just tested to switch the TargetFrameworkVersion of AzureCP from v4.6.1 to v4.7.2, and the result is pretty spectacular:
It reduced the number of dependencies from 115 (!!) to 18, so I'm very seriously thinking about changing that for good.

The downside is that SharePoint 2013+ require only 4.5, so some would need to update specifically for using AzureCP, but [4.5](https://docs.microsoft.com/lifecycle/products/microsoft-net-framework-45) is no longer supported and 4.7.2 was released [in 2018](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/lifecycle/products/microsoft-net-framework-472), so it shouldn't be so problematic

Hi @mhintner, my current state of knowledge is that you cannot use the same claims provider (class) with multiple SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuers because at runtime there is no way to determine what TrustedLoginProvider is currently calling.
Did you find a way to deal with that, but you're stuck on a different problem, or is it not working because of that?

Hi Yvand,

I figured out that the AzureCP configurations are working well the research we need to do is pure AzureAD configurations in Claim user attributes.
we have conflict between choosing the identifier and display name they both have the same attribute as (required & optional claim type) when we changed display name to name users permissions lost :/
attached mapping on AzureAD
![azureadmapping](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24433782/93208653-8e564f00-f765-11ea-9795-05eee2f7e4ba.PNG)

Ok, so AzureCP can set profiles properties in the site collections, but only for users that are added for the 1st time in the site collection.
So I suggest you you make your tests each time in a new temp site collection.

This feature does not rely on the configuration of the trust between Azure AD and SharePoint, it's a pure AzureCP configuration that you can see in central admin > security > AzureCP claims mapping page: the profile properties correspond to the column "PickerEntity metadata"

Unfortunately, you cannot set AzureCP with 2 SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer, that's not something that can be fixed in AzureCP as it's really a SharePoint limitation.
But there is a possible solution: you can associate AzureCP with 1, and use AzureCP.Developers.zip (that comes with each release) to createa a copy of AzureCP and associate it with the 2nd SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer. However, this approach requires dev skills in SharePoint and I don't recommend this approach if you're not familiar with it.

Can you sign-in to the SharePoint server as the application pool / farm account, open IE and try to browse the following sites:

* https://login.windows.net
* https://login.microsoftonline.com
* https://graph.microsoft.com

If one is not accessible / shows errors, AzureCP won't work, as they are all required for Graph API to work.

hi Fernando, your request couldn't have been with been in a better timing, because I'm working on implementing the support for national clouds deployments.
I just published [v18 beta](https://github.com/Yvand/AzureCP/releases/tag/18.0.20200717.1147) that includes this support.

Once you installed v18 and added your tenant to AzureCP, you need to set properties LoginServiceEndpoint and GraphServiceEndpoint manually using PowerShell (to the expected values for your cloud deployment):
```powershell
Add-Type -AssemblyName "AzureCP, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=65dc6b5903b51636"
$config = [azurecp.AzureCPConfig]::GetConfiguration("AzureCPConfig")
$tenant = $config.GetAzureTenantByName("XXX.onMicrosoft.com")
$tenant.LoginServiceEndpoint = "https://login.microsoftonline.us"
$tenant.GraphServiceEndpoint = "https://graph.microsoft.us"
$config.Update()
```

Add-Type -AssemblyName "AzureCP, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=65dc6b5903b51636"
$config = [azurecp.AzureCPConfig]::GetConfiguration("AzureCPConfig")
$tenant = $config.GetAzureTenantByName("XXX.onMicrosoft.com")
$tenant.LoginServiceEndpoint = "https://login.microsoftonline.us"
$tenant.GraphServiceEndpoint = "https://graph.microsoft.us"
$config.Update()

hi Fernando, the “Test Connection to Tenant” button uses only the data you enter for a new tenant (tenant name, client id, client secret / certificate), and for the rest it uses the default settings (including endpoints URLs).
Also, the endpoints URLs are per tenant, it's not a global setting.

In https://github.com/Yvand/AzureCP/releases/tag/18.0.20201112.1214, can you download AzureCP-18.0.20201112.1214-dependencies.zip and unzip it in a directory on your SharePoint server.
Then, run the following script to find which assemblies are missing:

```powershell
$assemblies = Get-ChildItem -Path "C:\Data\AzureCP-dependencies\*.dll"

You can visualize the actual traffic between AzureCP and Azure using [Fiddler](https://www.telerik.com/download/fiddler).
Start Fiddler on the SharePoint WFE and trust its root certificate (it's a dangerous action, be aware of what it means).
At the bottom left window of Fiddler, make sure it's monitoring "All processes".

Then, in the web.config of the SharePoint web app, configure the proxy like this:
```
<system.net>
    <defaultProxy useDefaultCredentials="true">
        <proxy proxyaddress="http://localhost:8888" bypassonlocal="False" />
    </defaultProxy>
</system.net>
```

Now, all people picker traffic from this web app will go through Fiddler

You can visualize the actual traffic between AzureCP and Azure using Fiddler <https://www.telerik.com/download/fiddler> .
Start Fiddler on the SharePoint WFE and trust its root certificate (it's a dangerous action, be aware of what it means).
At the bottom left window of Fiddler, make sure it's monitoring "All processes".

Then, in the web.config of the SharePoint web app, configure the proxy like this:

<system.net>
    <defaultProxy useDefaultCredentials="true">
        <proxy proxyaddress="http://localhost:8888" bypassonlocal="False" />
    </defaultProxy>
</system.net>

Now, all people picker traffic from this web app will go through Fiddler

Trusting Fiddler root certificate means that it will be added to your server trusted root authorities. It will be returned with this command:

```powershell
Get-ChildItem -Path "Cert:\LocalMachine\Root" | Where-Object{$_.Subject -like  "CN=DO_NOT_TRUST_FiddlerRoot"}
```
As a consequence, any certificate issued by this one will be considered valid by your machine. Malicious code might use that.
So, just don't forget to remove it after you're done with the investigations.

I bet it's a certificate issue, probably you did not run Windows Update for a long time on this VM, so you are missing some certificate authorities that are required to trust and access https://graph.microsoft.us and https://login.microsoftonline.us.

You can validate the actual problem by dumping the details of the WebException
As long as Invoke-WebRequest fails on both, AzureCP will not work

After closing Fiddler, did you remove the proxy configuration in the web.config, where you set Fiddler as the proxy?
Can you also detail what changes you made?

I made changes to disable: TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1, SSL 2.0, SSL 3.0,  and RC4,
enable TLS 1.2 and SchUseStrongCryto for the .NetFramework


---- PS Script below ----

reg add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Ciphers\RC4 40/128" /f
reg add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Ciphers\RC4 40/128" /v Enabled /t REG_DWORD /d 00000000
reg add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Ciphers\RC4 56/128" /f
reg add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Ciphers\RC4 56/128" /v Enabled /t REG_DWORD /d 00000000
reg add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Ciphers\RC4 128/128" /f 
reg add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Ciphers\RC4 128/128" /v Enabled /t REG_DWORD /d 00000000

#Tighten up the .NET Framework
$NetRegistryPath = "HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\.NETFramework\v4.0.30319"
New-ItemProperty -Path $NetRegistryPath -Name "SchUseStrongCrypto" -Value "1" -PropertyType DWORD -Force | Out-Null

$NetRegistryPath = "HKLM:\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\.NETFramework\v4.0.30319"
New-ItemProperty -Path $NetRegistryPath -Name "SchUseStrongCrypto" -Value "1" -PropertyType DWORD -Force | Out-Null

$ProtocolList = @("SSL 2.0","SSL 3.0","TLS 1.0", "TLS 1.1", "TLS 1.2")
$ProtocolSubKeyList = @("Client", "Server")
$DisabledByDefault = "DisabledByDefault"
$Enabled = "Enabled"
$registryPath = "HKLM:\\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Protocols\"
foreach($Protocol in $ProtocolList)
{
	Write-Host " In 1st For loop"
	foreach($key in $ProtocolSubKeyList)
	{
		$currentRegPath = $registryPath + $Protocol + "\" + $key
		Write-Host " Current Registry Path $currentRegPath"

		if(!(Test-Path $currentRegPath))
		{
			Write-Host "creating the registry"
			New-Item -Path $currentRegPath -Force | out-Null
		}

		if($Protocol -eq "TLS 1.2")
		{
			Write-Host "Working for TLS 1.2"
			New-ItemProperty -Path $currentRegPath -Name $DisabledByDefault -Value "0" -PropertyType DWORD -Force | Out-Null
			New-ItemProperty -Path $currentRegPath -Name $Enabled -Value "1" -PropertyType DWORD -Force | Out-Null
		}
		else
		{
			Write-Host "Working for other protocol"
			New-ItemProperty -Path $currentRegPath -Name $DisabledByDefault -Value "1" -PropertyType DWORD -Force | Out-Null
			New-ItemProperty -Path $currentRegPath -Name $Enabled -Value "0" -PropertyType DWORD -Force | Out-Null
		}
	}
}

Ok. Finally!!
The solution to my problems was to do the TLS/SSL config changes above with one additional one listed below.
I also removed the proxy from the web.config of the web app (I don't remember putting it there but....)

It is all working as expected now.

Thanks a lot Yvan.
Fernando




reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SChannel\KeyExchangeAlgorithms\Diffie-Hellman" /f 
reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SChannel\KeyExchangeAlgorithms\Diffie-Hellman" /v Enabled /t REG_DWORD /d 00000000

Somehow, some assemblies that AzureCP depends on are missing in the SharePoint server.
You can unzip AzureCP.wsp using [7-zip](https://www.7-zip.org/), and compare the assemblies in the archive with the ones present in the GAC of the machine (C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\assembly\GAC_MSIL) to find which ones are missing.
You can also apply the PowerShell script in https://yvand.github.io/AzureCP/Install-AzureCP.html to automatically install all of them

@abhishek0818 it's difficult to understand the exact issue.
AzureCP queries Azure AD attributes that it is configured to query. You can visualize this configuration in central admin > Security > AzureCP claims mapping page.

.NET framework is quite up to date and I'm not sure it'll update the assembly.
Let's try to update [System.Net.Http](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Net.Http), but it's not that straightforward:

1. In the Visual Studio project you created, add [NuGet package](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Net.Http) as a reference. It will download System.Net.Http.dll locally
2. Add System.Net.Http.dll that you just downloaded to the GAC of **all** SharePoint servers:

```powershell
[System.Reflection.Assembly]::Load("System.EnterpriseServices, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a") | Out-Null
$publish = New-Object System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.Publish
$publish.GacInstall("C:\VSProject\System.Net.Http.dll")
Write-Host "Assembly was successfully added to the GAC."
```

@Yvand nice to meet! First of all, thanks for your great work regarding this product! I'm the one who can answer your question, and offcourse i'm willing to share as much detail i can. If you have morge questions than answered here below, just ask. For now, i will limit myself to only the relevant parts (as far as there would be stuff left out).

@dvanboven put me on track wat was happening, the issues that came around, en my luck was my programming and Sharepoint background. Not of the level of expert, but enough to be able tot troubleshoot dll issues, GAC, x64 or x32 relevants, view log files and so on.

So to the point! First of all was during registering the dependecies. When running it, there was an error regarding a failure during running the script as mentioned on your website:

$assemblies = Get-ChildItem -Path "C:\Options\AzureAD\AzureCP\*.dll"
[System.Reflection.Assembly]::Load("System.EnterpriseServices, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a")
$publish = New-Object System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.Publish
foreach ($assembly in $assemblies)
{
    $filePath = $assembly.FullName
    $assemblyFullName = [System.Reflection.AssemblyName]::GetAssemblyName($filePath).FullName

    try
    {
        $assemblyInGAC = [System.Reflection.Assembly]::Load($assemblyFullName)
        Write-Host "Assembly $assemblyFullName is already present in the GAC"

        if ($assemblyInGAC.FullName -match "AzureCP, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=65dc6b5903b51636")
        {
            # AzureCP must always be overwritten because each version has the same full name
            $publish.GacRemove($assemblyInGAC)
            $publish.GacInstall($filePath)
            Write-Host "Assembly $assemblyFullName sucessfully re-added to the GAC" -ForegroundColor Green
        }
    }
    catch [System.IO.FileNotFoundException] 
    {
        # Assembly.Load throws a FileNotFoundException if assembly is not found in the GAC: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.io.filenotfoundexception?view=netframework-4.8
        Write-Host "Adding assembly $assemblyFullName to the GAC"
        $publish.GacInstall($filePath)
        Write-Host "Assembly $assemblyFullName sucessfully added to the GAC" -ForegroundColor Green
    }
}

As this could be referencing to one of the other dll's not registering, or not being installed at all, we started diving in here. Because i wasn't quite sure if:
$assemblyInGAC = [System.Reflection.Assembly]::Load($assemblyFullName)
would throw a catch, we did the resgistration through a loop. Trying to register all files by hand.
It seems to work, but deregistering first and doing a re-register, was failing on Newtonsoft.Json.dll. I could imagine that parsing results with such an old version, could be causing troubles.

So when diving in to this, it seemed that even a gacutil /u /f newtonsoft.json (warning, i do this from the info out of my head. so /uf or /f) which means a forced unregister, wasn't working. The MSI installer package is locking this file.
From my persitence to refresh this registration once again, i removed the lock from the registry by removing the key:
[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Classes\Installer\Assemblies\Global]
de-register works. re-register works also.

After this worked, i saw other errors. One of them pointed me at the WCF data components. I could imagine that the newtonsoft.json dll was referenced here also. So first i tried a reconfigure, but it required a fresh install. This fixes more errors in the event viewer.

But what seems later, after doing some testing. And the need for reinstalling the AzureCP module (i will come back with the reason below), it seems that after removing / uninstalling the CP module, the newtonsoft.json is also uninstalled.
So when this happens, or after a reboot, you get weird errors. Not strange at all, but if you're not awaire, you must do some investigation.

After knowing this, i fixed the dll again. Not yet restored the registry lock yet, but first did some "sharepoint configuration wizard". This one showed other errors. First time run, it run weird (only the option to disconnect from the farm) and a lot errors (before restoring the newtonsoft dll). 
later on (now the .dll was restored) some error that make more sense. They can be split in two area's. 

part1: MSI installer locations nog available:
did a fresh download, made the locations available again, and a lot of reconfiguring happend. (probably some requirements of updates).

part2: content databases which wheren't upgraded yet:
It seems that the movement, migration, upgrade? was done. But after some patching, or after the upgrade to the SP2016 enviroment, there were some databases pending upgrade.

There where some features missing, old references, which aren't used anymore.

So i used: FeatureAdmin from: https://github.com/achimismaili/featureadmin
great tool! After doing some fixing, checks, and cleanup, i was able te do a succesfull sharepoint configuration wizard.
Afterwards, i could the db upgrade by the specified commands in the eventviewer and some information i worked out (sorry, didn't stored the references) but it was the inplace upgrade of the content DB.

After finishing all this, i rebooted the server, and everything was fine. "Clean" event log or at least for what was possible.

From this point, we created a new back-up and started working on the AzureCP tool again. See the information David provided.
Because we can't reproduce the error we started this case with, we do a removal and fresh re-install every time. It seems that the test of adding a user, which should trigger a claim request, is cached. So to make sure we trigger a new request, we re-install the application. Sometime, remove, reboot, and re-install. After the remove, reboot, we had a lot of errors. newtonsoft.json again (grrrr). So restoring the file from the folder you provided on the site, i restored the GAC registry key regarding this file. So it won't be removed again.

I specified as much i can remember, we experencied, so you get a clear view.
In the meanwhile, the server and Sharepoint is patched as far as Windows Update delivers.
So basically, it was a combination of lefover from some patches, hanging dll (re?)registration, and an not upgraded content database. Also missing MSI files which where required to do some re-register / re-install.

For now, we still love to get this one working. I think it's usefuller for future references to open up a new ticket.
But, do you still want to continue with us? Hoping to find a solution to the claim request issues?
The good news here, i will be helping @dvanboven to faster respond to some checks.
Would you like me to open a new ticket? Then we leave this history behind.

Kind regards, Wim

In AzureCP.GetGroupMembershipFromAzureADAsync(), await on tasks somehow causes the hang:
```c#
IGraphServiceUsersCollectionPage userResult = await tenant.GraphService.Users.Request().Filter(filter).GetAsync().ConfigureAwait(false);
```

This is somehow caused by the way ASP.NET runs async tasks.
Workaround found: instead of awaiting on the async task directly, run it in a parent task, and await on the parent task:
```c#
IGraphServiceUsersCollectionPage userResult = await Task.Run(() => tenant.GraphService.Users.Request().Filter(filter).GetAsync()).ConfigureAwait(false);
```

AzureCP allows you to choose what Azure AD attribute should be used as the unique identifier. You can do that in Central Administration > Security > AzureCP global configuration, and set the "user identifier property".
Of course, this attribute must match the one you set in the Azure AD Enterprise Application for SharePoint.
Note that the Azure AD application created for AzureCP is not playing any role here.

Is there a way to add additional options to that list though? For instance, the On-Prem UPN attribute, or the DOMAIN\username formatted-attribute (not sure what it’s called)? I know these are available attributes in Azure... We use them for the Trusted Identity Provider....

Unfortunately this list is not dynamic, it is a simple enumeration type.
I will update it to include all the [possible properties for User class](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/api/resources/user?view=graph-rest-1.0#properties), but you will need to update AzureCP to use it.

The format shown in people columns is determined by the display name of the user profile, set in the User Profile Application.
AzureCP itself has a very limited (almost none) ability to set the format displayed in this column, you can consider that it is not playing a role.

Ah, I understand now that this is a UPS configuration problem.

Does AzureCP work with profiles imported from on-prem AD when using Azure Active Directory Sync? When I set up the User Profile Service application to import from our on-prem AD, I ran into a problem where users authenticated via Azure AD do not start using the imported profile. 

Essentially it led to a case where there were two user profiles for the same user: "domain\testuser" and "i:0e.t|azuread|testuser@domain", and these profiles were accessed separately depending on authentication method. 

Or should I be importing from AzureAD directly / what are the requirements to ensure the Azure-authenticated user grabs the imported profile?  

I really appreciate the help & I apologize for my inexperience on the subject.

This area is poorly documented, so it's perfectly understandable that you are confused.
The important thing to understand are:
- "i:0#.w|domain\testuser" and "i:0e.t|azuread|testuser@domain" are NOT the same user, as far as SharePoint is concerned they are 2 completely different users
- User Profile Service application has nothing to do with permissions, its only purpose is to populate metadata about the users
Closing this issue, feel free to reopen it if needed

Hi @vargasfe, the issues that you describe are related to [this uservoice](https://feedback.azure.com/forums/169401-azure-active-directory/suggestions/36274663-sign-in-to-sharepoint-2016-with-guest-accounts-is)

I verified that the solution implemented by the Azure AD team and described in the uservoice above works: when you set the source attribute of nameidentifier to "user.localuserprincipalname", both B2B and MSA guest accounts get a consistent value in the SAML token (in format user_mail.com#EXT#@Tenant.onmicrosoft.com).

For this to work well with AzureCP, you need to change AzureCP configuration to set "User identifier for 'Guest' users" to UserPrincipalName. Of course if you have existing Guest users added with previous configuration, they may not be able to sign-in after this change, and may need to be migrated to match the new value.

I plan to write a full article on this topic but I'm short in time for the moment. Please test this config and let me know if you have questions or comments
