@sergey-tihon I am happy to discuss the security concerns and determine the best implementation, I have much to learn on this area.

While using the Windows certificate store is technically feasible, it has significant drawbacks:

- The administrator must ensure that the certificate is present in all SharePoint servers, with proper permissions.
- The list of accounts that need access to the private key is potentially large: all SharePoint processes may use AzureCP, and not only: PowerShell scripts may also use AzureCP (through SharePoint API). It makes such a list hard to maintain, especially across multiple machines.

Considering this, I decided to store the private key in the persisted object that holds AzureCP configuration. The benefits are:

- Setting/updating the certificate is centralized and super easy: the admin just needs to give the certificate to AzureCP.
- Currently, yes it uses a hardcoded password, but the level of security is strictly the same as it is today with the client secret, which is stored in clear text in the configuration database.

With that said, I realize it's bad to use a hardcoded password to store a private key, but I'm not an expert on security and I don't know how to use a secure password that does not depend on the machine or the account. Maybe using the SharePoint passphrase could be an option, I can dig in this area. Do you have any suggestion?

What do you think about storing secrets inside `Secure Store Service`?
> [The Secure Store Service is a claims-aware authorization service that includes an encrypted database for storing credentials.](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/administration/secure-store-service-planning)

Drawback: One more dependency and more complicated configuration.
Benefit: Secure encrypted storage to secrets provided by SharePoint.

https://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/20110.sharepoint-retrieving-credentials-from-the-secure-store-application-using-c.aspx (never use it before)

In theory it's the perfect solution, in practice, it makes the configuration and the implementation significantly more complex.
Besides, from my experience the Secure Store is not commonly used, so it would also require a particular effort to document how to properly configure it for AzureCP, including the maintenance (update the secret).
It also creates a very significant dependency: if for some reason Secure Store stops working, AzureCP also stops working, which would be pretty bad.

On my side I investigated if I can use somehow the SharePoint passphrase to encode/decode a secret. Short answer is no, no public API allows it.
I tried using reflection to call internal method Microsoft.SharePoint.Administration.SPCredentialManager.EncryptWithApplicationCredentialKey() but I got a "SPException: Cannot retrieve the information for application credential key".

Then I prose to store certificate and `ClientCertificatePrivateKeyPassword` the same way as you stored `ApplicationSecret` and open new issue `Implement Secure Secret Store` for refactoring that will encrypt all secrets or more them in secure place. This should not postpone `V16` release.
You mean to keep the current implementation as-is for v16, and plan the implementation of the Secure Store for a future version?

I am asking this because by default `AccessTokenLifetime`  is 1 hour. So, token expires every hour and SharePoint redirect us to AAD for login (not very pleasant user experience)

[Configurable token lifetimes in Azure Active Directory (Preview)](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/active-directory-configurable-token-lifetimes)  works till Nov 1, and will be replaced by [authentication session management with Conditional Access](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/conditional-access/howto-conditional-access-session-lifetime) that is premium feature that require additional licenses.

That is why usefulness of AzureCP for no-premium Azure AD users is questionable for me after Nov 1, 2019.

This is interesting, I was not aware about this.
I agree that the default lifetime of 1h will be a painful limitation on non-premium Azure AD tenants after configurable token lifetime feature will be retired on November 1.
But I don't see what can be done on AzureCP/SharePoint side to deal with this. Silently refreshing the access token on behalf of the user is not possible, only the user can refresh it.

I see the update on MSDN: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/active-directory-configurable-token-lifetimes

> After hearing from customers during the preview, we've implemented authentication session management capabilities in Azure AD Conditional Access. You can use this new feature to configure refresh token lifetimes by setting sign in frequency. After **May 1, 2020** you will not be able to use Configurable Token Lifetime policy to configure session and refresh tokens. **You can still configure access token lifetimes after the deprecation**.

Does last sentence mean that access token lifetime will be configurable  after `May 1, 2020` and it is enough for AzureCP?

it is not a concern, it is `new hope` 

I see the solution for my initial concern in following sentence
> You can still configure access token lifetimes after the deprecation.

Even after deprecation of `Configurable token lifetimes in Azure Active Directory (Preview)`, we will be able to increate `access token lifetimes` (even without Azure AD Premium).

This means that we can increase `access token lifetimes` from default `1h` to lets say `12h` and do not re-login/redirect users every hour (FedAuth cookie will be valid for `12h` as well)

@Yvand I just want to verify that I correctly undestand this new `sentence` and how AzureCP really works.

The lifetime of the AzureCP access token is totally decorrelated from the user sessions.
If its access token expires in the middle of an active user session (for example, during a POST), AzureCP will merely renew it (which will not cause a sign-out/re-authentication of the user).
User session is valid as long as the FedAuth cookie (and its associated SAML token) is valid, AzureCP never touches this.

Probably I misunderstood something, but I always though that lifetime of `FedAuth` cookie is equal to SAML token lifetime.

As a final step of login SharePoint receive POST request to `_trust/default.aspx` with SAML token
```xml
<t:RequestSecurityTokenResponse xmlns:t="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/02/trust">

        <wsu:Created xmlns:wsu="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-utility-1.0.xsd">2020-02-18T16:32:40.915Z</wsu:Created>
        <wsu:Expires xmlns:wsu="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-utility-1.0.xsd">2020-02-19T04:37:40.915Z</wsu:Expires>
    </t:Lifetime>
    ...
    <t:TokenType>http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/oasis-wss-saml-token-profile-1.1#SAMLV1.1</t:TokenType>
    <t:RequestType>http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/02/trust/Issue</t:RequestType>
    <t:KeyType>http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/NoProofKey</t:KeyType>
</t:RequestSecurityTokenResponse>
```

Is there other way to increase SAML token lifetime (with default value `1h` for access token)?

I ran into a similar issue today when using the ShareGate migration tool to move a large document library to an offsite SharePoint location that was set up to authenticate using AzureCP. 

Using ShareGate's browser based authentication, it is not able to renew the token automatically so the migration just fails after 50 minutes when the token expires.
If I'm simply accessing the same site with IE or Chrome using the same account I have no issues staying logged in for days at a time without needing to re-authenticate.

I had to create a new Azure AD policy setting the AccessTokenLifetime to 24 hours and assign it to the enterprise application set up for SharePoint and AzureCP. Though the migration it seems is still not going to complete within 24 hours..
We do have a premium Azure AD but as far as I can tell there are no options to simply extend the AccessTokenLifetime for a user or application in the conditional access policies.

The Sharepoint AzureAD application is using implicit grant with ID tokens for authentication. You might be able to implement the following for the AzureCP

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/v2-oauth2-implicit-grant-flow#refreshing-tokens

**Refreshing tokens**
The implicit grant does not provide refresh tokens. Both id_tokens and access_tokens will expire after a short period of time, so your app must be prepared to refresh these tokens periodically. To refresh either type of token, you can perform the same hidden iframe request from above using the prompt=none parameter to control the identity platform's behavior. If you want to receive a new id_token, be sure to use id_token in the response_type and scope=openid, as well as a nonce parameter.

Hmm, where do you persist `ClientCertificatePrivateKeyPassword` ? I still see hardcoded value in `dev` branch, but cannot find line where you persist `password` that we type when upload certificate.

ClientCertificatePrivateKeyPassword is not persisted, it's a const used to export/import the certificate (with its private key) that is persisted in the configuration database.
The password you type in the configuration page is used only to decrypt the .pfx file (it assumes it is password protected).
It looks like your .pfx file is not password protected, and importing it fails because it expects a password is required.

Check Permissions functionality uses a token that is valid for 24h, and bound to the current site collection.
If you wish to test it in a reliable way, you should either:

- Test it in a new site collection
- Or lower its lifetime to 1 min using the cmdlet below:

```powershell
$cs = [Microsoft.SharePoint.Administration.SPWebService]::ContentService
# Default value:   New-TimeSpan -Days 1
$cs.TokenTimeout = New-TimeSpan -Minutes 1
$cs.Update()
```
For Check Permissions which functions called from SPClaimProvider class? or from Azure CP code?
It will call either one of the AzureCP.FillClaimsForEntity() methods

Not as-is, as AzureCP is compiled for .NET 4.5, which is not supported by SharePoint 2010.
If you wish to use it on SharePoint 2010, you will have to compile the source code yourself for this version.

It's a great question.
The reason why AzureCP does not return O365 groups is that when it gets group membership of the user, it sets "securityEnabledOnly: true", which excludes them.
I tested with the [Graph explorer](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/graph-explorer) to set "securityEnabledOnly: false" and it includes O365 groups as you would expect.

So I can change the code to retrieve them, or make this customizable by the administrator.
What do you think?

For reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/api/user-getmembergroups?view=graph-rest-1.0
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/api/resources/group?view=graph-rest-1.0
https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/graph-explorer

On v13, my People Pickers return all groups (including the O365 Groups) when I add the _role_ claim type to my TrustedIdentityTokenIssuer. Hi @AussieDavo you can use method ClaimTypeConfigCollection.UpdateIdentifierForGuestUsers():

```powershell
Add-Type -AssemblyName "AzureCP, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=65dc6b5903b51636"
$config = [azurecp.AzureCPConfig]::GetConfiguration("AzureCPConfig")
$config.ClaimTypes.UpdateIdentifierForGuestUsers([azurecp.AzureADObjectProperty]::UserPrincipalName)
$config.Update()
```

PnP is implemented to help with complex provisioning and management of routines.

**Connect-PnPOnline -Url https://SharePoint.url.com -Credentials $cred

Hi @Yvand ,
I believe I have the same problem. It seems that there is no consistency in the UPN set within the SAML token presented to SharePoint by the Azure AD Enterprise Application.

I am using AzureCP primarily for Guest account access to my on-prem SharePoint 2016 environment. I am getting a mix of UPN's being presented for Guest users, some in the "username_domain.com#ext#@tenantname.onmicrosoft.com" format and some in the "username@domain.com" format.

Many of these Guest accounts have their own Office 365 tenancies which I believe may be causing the issue. I have not had enough time to fully test all scenarios but believe that if a Guest account has an Office 365 tenancy and also has an Exchange mailbox in Office 365 then the UPN is presented in the "username@domain.com" format within the SAML token. In all other scenarios the UPN is presented in the "username_domain.com#ext#@tenantname.onmicrosoft.com" format within the SAML token.

I have managed to work around this by switching the "User identifier for 'Guest' users" to "Mail" within the AzureCP global configuration and then using PowerShell to add the users Mail UPN to the site collection:
`New-SPUser -UserAlias 'i:0e.t|azuread|username@domain.com' -Web 'https://ourdomain.com/sites/sitecollection/'
`
`Set-SPUser -Identity 'i:0e.t|azuread|username@domain.com'  -Web 'https://ourdomain.com/sites/sitecollection/'  -Group 'Site Visitors'`
After this I then revert the "User identifier for 'Guest' users" setting back to "UserPrincipalName" in the AzureCP global configuration.

After this I now have both permissions set for either UPN:
i:0e.t|azuread|username@domain.com
i:0e.t|azuread|username_domain.com#ext#@tenantname.onmicrosoft.com
This way if the user logs in with either, they will still have the correct permissions set. This is however not ideal as it requires a SharePoint Admin to configure all Guest permissions.

Could I have configured something incorrectly? Or is there a way to make sure all Guest users are consistently authenticated?

We played a lot with B2B and AzureCP.
If my recolections are correct here are some prerequisite (@bartbilliet can you re-read):
- federate authentication from SharePoint to one tenant (main tenant)
- naturaly you should add the main tenant as well and show guests for this one
- to be able to use people picker you should add other tenant to azurecp but you need to hide guest accounts for them
- for the authentication of a B2B user to be successfull you need to make sure the invitation was successfull (i.e. share a ressource from you main tenant and check access. SharePoint Online could do it. Or check with Azure AD)

A (few) word on why all this (mainly hide guest for secondary tenants):

It seems that when authenticating with Azure AD B2B there are two situations.
- When you are a B2B user from another tenant the token_id will contain your proper UPN.
- When you are a B2B user from a public account (i.e. Microsoft Account liken hotmail or live.com, or a gmail account) you get a token_id containing the UPN of the guest user in your primary tenant. This UPN contains "#ext#".

So for SharePoint this does mean that access rights and user definition should be set accordingly. Which is admittedly kind of a mess. Especially so when using people picker with only one main tenant known.
The reason is that people picker will use the UPN from the account selected in it. And with only one main tenant this allways returns the upns with "#ext#". This is not a problem for Microsoft Accounts but for accounts from other tenant thiis does break things.

To alleviate that we added:
- the possibility to address other tenants
- the possibility to say for which guest accounts should be shown
- a decorelation between guest accounts (if a UPN without "#ext#" does exist for a user hide any other users with the same UPN but with "#ext#")

This will allow you to set rights correctly in a SharePoint with AzureCP. Naturally the limitation is that you should have contact or access to administration of other tenants because AzureCP needs access to their directory for the feature mentionned.

@cblomart in the following statement are you saying you have creating a work around?

> To alleviate that we added:
> 
> the possibility to address other tenants
> the possibility to say for which guest accounts should be shown
> a decorelation between guest accounts (if a UPN without "#ext#" does exist for a user hide any other users with the same UPN but with "#ext#")
> This will allow you to set rights correctly in a SharePoint with AzureCP. Naturally the limitation is that you should have contact or access to administration of other tenants because AzureCP needs access to their directory for the feature mentionned.

The guest accounts we are having problems with are not in other tenants myname@mycompany.com  they do not get the #ext# ---  Does not matter if has #ext# because than they could access the SharePoint account.

This was implemented a while ago to demonstrate sharepoint (on permises) integration with azure ad.

For your second remark... maybe I was not clear... or i don’t understand the issue. 

The understanding i have is the if there is no « #ext# » in the upn present in the openid token_id then the account was directly validated via azure ad. Most commonly present with a tenant.

Could this be solved by using the Mail/emailaddress attribute rather than the UserPrincipalName attribute throughout the authentication process?

__________________________________________
For Example

**Azure AD Enterprise Application Configuration:**
Name identifier value: user.mail

**SharePoint 2016 on-prem config:**
`$realm = "urn:sharepoint:ourdomain.com"
$wsfedurl="https://login.microsoftonline.com/GUID/wsfed"
$filepath="D:\Temp\certificate.cer"
$cert = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2($filepath)
New-SPTrustedRootAuthority -Name "AzureAD" -Certificate $cert

$map = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "mail" -LocalClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress"
$map2 = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "name" -SameAsIncoming
$map3 = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/givenname" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "GivenName" -SameAsIncoming
$map4 = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/surname" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "SurName" -SameAsIncoming
$ap = New-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer -Name "AzureAD" -Description "SharePoint secured by Azure AD" -realm $realm -ImportTrustCertificate $cert -ClaimsMappings $map,$map2,$map3,$map4 -SignInUrl $wsfedurl -IdentifierClaim "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress"`

**AzureCP Config:**
Global Config = "Mail" for both "User identifier for 'Member' users" and "User identifier for 'Guest' users"

Guys, can you please check and confirm if your issue is correctly described in [this user voice](https://feedback.azure.com/forums/169401-azure-active-directory/suggestions/36274663-sign-in-to-sharepoint-2016-with-guest-accounts-is)?
If that is so, in the short term:
- Consider to vote/comment on the entry
- Starting with AzureCP 13, you can choose what attribute to use for Guest account: 
  - By default it uses "mail": it works only with B2B Guest accounts (accounts that exist in another AAD tenant)
  - You can change to UserPrincipalName instead: it will work only with MSA Guest accounts (e.g. Hotmail/Gmail accounts)

In the future, Azure AD team needs to fix this by using a unified attribute for all Guest accounts (which should always be the email address). The more votes the user voice has, the quicker we have a chance to get a fix (with a formal status).

> This was implemented a while ago to demonstrate sharepoint (on permises) integration with azure ad.
>

> The understanding i have is the if there is no « #ext# » in the upn present in the openid token_id then the account was directly validated via azure ad. Most commonly present with a tenant.

Either way, we are having issues that are guests from custom domains.  They are missing the #ext#.  They get through to SharePoint, but because the UPN with the #ext# is not in SharePoint users are getting "This site has not been shared with you"

I am not saying that what was implemented is a complete solution.
By adding the tenant of the custom domain you know of, you can add access to users directly from their azure ad without the "#ext#" and they get access properly.
The limitation is that you need to have access to the tenant azure ad to enumerate users.

@Yvand is right in saying that the solution lies within the azure ad team.

They should provide either:
- a way to distinguish MSA accounts from the graph api. I say that because on the azure portal on the azure ad users page, you can see the source of the user: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/b2b/user-properties#after-invitation-redemption
- seemless usage of attribute: as @Yvand has proposed in the uservoice, attributes should be consistent. Be it mail or upn, the value recieve in the token should match the one in azure ad.

I voted on the [uservoice](https://feedback.azure.com/forums/169401-azure-active-directory/suggestions/36274663-sign-in-to-sharepoint-2016-with-guest-accounts-is) as this make much sense but i think that this is practically difficult tothe azure ad team, otherwise they would have done it this way.

Having the "source" attribute in graph api may provide a way to handle MSA account programmatically in AzureCP. Some work from microsoft is still needed there also.

Hi guys, I come back to this old topic as I tested a workaround that works well:

In the enterprise application in Azure AD: set claim types name / NameIdentifier to user.mail (instead of user.userprincipalname), this will fix the inconsistent usage of “#EXT#” for Guest accounts.
For this to work:

- AAD Connect must be configured to sync mail property of AD OnPrem users
- Azure AD cloud users don’t have their property mail set by default, so it must be set explicitly otherwise they won’t be able to sign-in.
- In AzureCP, set the "user identifier" of both Members and Guests to “Mail” in AzureCP global configuration page.

Is this issue still in your radar?
I know it fixed me Yvand.  Now true Azure AD Guests and Azure AD Tenant to Tenant Guest can access SharePoint without any issue.

Hi @Yvand I made this change in my environment last weekend and eventually got it working. I found that the issue was also lying withing my SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer SPClaimTypeMapping configuration.

Previously I had configured my SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer like this:

`$realm = "urn:sharepoint:URL"`
`$wsfedurl="https://login.microsoftonline.com/GUID/wsfed"`
`$filepath="D:\Temp\latest.cer"`
`$cert = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2($filepath)
New-SPTrustedRootAuthority -Name "AzureAD" -Certificate $cert`

`$map = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "name" -LocalClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/upn"`
`$map2 = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType
"http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/givenname" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "GivenName" -SameAsIncoming`
`$map3 = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/surname" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "SurName" -SameAsIncoming`
`$ap = New-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer -Name "AzureAD" -Description "SharePoint secured by Azure AD" -realm $realm -ImportTrustCertificate $cert -ClaimsMappings $map,$map2,$map3 -SignInUrl $wsfedurl -IdentifierClaim "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name"`

However after mapping the incoming claim type for emailaddress to the local claim type upn it then started working as expected. Here is what I did to resolve the issue:

`$realm = "urn:sharepoint:URL"`
`$wsfedurl="https://login.microsoftonline.com/GUID/wsfed"`
`$filepath="D:\Temp\latest.cer"`
`$cert = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2($filepath)
New-SPTrustedRootAuthority -Name "AzureAD" -Certificate $cert`

`$map = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "emailaddress" -LocalClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/upn"`
`$map2 = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/givenname" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "GivenName" -SameAsIncoming`
`$map3 = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/surname" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "SurName" -SameAsIncoming`
`$ap = New-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer -Name "AzureAD" -Description "SharePoint secured by Azure AD" -realm $realm -ImportTrustCertificate $cert -ClaimsMappings $map,$map2,$map3 -SignInUrl $wsfedurl -IdentifierClaim "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress"`

The only issue I have now is that when a new user gets added to a SharePoint group the "Work Email" field is not set so the user does not get an email invitation.

I was thinking of adding another SPClaimTypeMapping by adding the following to my script:

`$map1 = New-SPClaimTypeMapping -IncomingClaimType "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "emailaddress" -SameAsIncoming`

But not sure if I can use duplicate IncomingClaimType's?

I'm interested to see how others have setup their SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer and if there is an easier way to add, remove and change claim type mappings. I'm aware that AzureCP has a Claims Types Config but not sure of the best way to set it up. Does anyone have a screenshot of a working AzureCP Claim Types Config?

Here is a screenshot of my working AzureCP Claim Types Config (apart form the email invitation functionality):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5260349/57340999-d762c000-717b-11e9-8657-e84ba1ba6d22.png)

I solved the issue in my previous comment about:

> The only issue I have now is that when a new user gets added to a SharePoint group the "Work Email" field is not set so the user does not get an email invitation.
 
All I needed to do was add the "Email" attribute to the PickerEntity Metadata for my main claim type: "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/upn"

Like this: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5260349/63071242-da7f0080-bf61-11e9-9cb2-ae946893251c.png)


Found in the in the AzureCP Claim types configuration in central admin: http://server_name/_admin/azurecp/ClaimTypesConfig.aspx

Now the email address gets populated as soon as the user is added by people picker. As a result invitation emails are now working for these users too.

Hi @chrisbrownie this feature is actually more complex to develop than I thought: 
As you can see [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53707703/allow-to-find-only-users-members-of-a-specific-group-in-1-query), Microsoft Graph does not allow to create a filter on user and group in 1 query, so I cannot make a query like this:
`/users?$filter=(startswith(UserPrincipalName, 'aad') and memberOf eq 'GroupID')`

So if I want to implement this feature, I need to completely change the logic, to get alll the members of the restricted group defined, and then for each user returned, check if he matches the input in the people picker.

Given the complexity, unless I get more feedback that this would be a very needed feature, I'm not going to implement it, sorry.

A claims provider cannot ("normally") write in the User Profile Application, it can only populate metadata of the entity (user) in the site collection IF the entity is created for the 1st time.
So in AzureCP you can add PickerEntity metadata for the email and the MobilePhone to populate them in the user properties in the site collection, but it will not write them in the user profile because it's not supposed to do this.
To test if this is working fine, create a new site collection to avoid conflict with existing entities (permissions)

Line is red because AzureCP didn't find the claim type "http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/role" in the SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer.
So either you use another claim type for the groups (and you can update the red line with this claim type), or you didn't set any and you need to add it in the SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer.

Closing, got it working from your other repository notes LDAPCP, totally removed and re-installed.

How to remove for others having issues:

```
#######################################
####### ONLY USE IF YOU HAVE MESSED UP --- UNINSTALL MESS IF NOT WORKING ########################################

#Uninstall-SPSolution -Identity "AzureCP.wsp"

Get-SPClaimProvider| ?{$_.DisplayName -like "AzureCP"}| Remove-SPClaimProvider

# Identify all LDAPCP features installed on the farm
Get-SPFeature| ?{$_.DisplayName -like 'AzureCP*'}| fl DisplayName, Scope, Id, RootDirectory

# Deactivate LDAPCP features ############# Might need to run the script a number of times to complete the clean up.
Get-SPFeature| ?{$_.DisplayName -like 'AzureCP*'}| Disable-SPFeature -Confirm:$false -force
# Uninstall LDAPCP features
Get-SPFeature| ?{$_.DisplayName -like 'AzureCP*'}| Uninstall-SPFeature -Confirm:$false -force

#Found that running the two above did not require me to run the following ***How do you know what object id to use***
stsadm -o deleteconfigurationobject -id 5D306A02-A262-48AC-8C44-BDB927620227

Remove-SPSolution "AzureCP.wsp" -Confirm:$false -force



```

Apart from still being a beta, v12 has breaking changes compared to previous versions, especially for group permissions.
To test permissions reliably, you need to create a new site collection, so that entities already added (regardless if there where deleted or not) do not interfere with the ones you are trying now.
With v12, assuming you use default claim types configuration:
- group permissions are created with group IDs
- nested groups are working

Of course, for group permissions to work, augmentation must be enabled in AzureCP settings

I suggest you try to reset the configuration and add the tenants again. You have 2 options:

- Otherwise you can use PowerShell:
```powershell

```

Ah yes, sorry I forgot to mention that you need to reset the claim types list after you updated AzureCP.
You have 3 options:
- Central admin > AzureCP global settings page > "Reset AzureCP Configuration" (but that will also remove all tenants registered)
- Central admin > AzureCP claim types config page (assuming it displays with no error) > "Reset"
- PowerShell: run this script:
```powershell
Add-Type -AssemblyName "AzureCP, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=65dc6b5903b51636"
$config = [azurecp.AzureCPConfig]::GetConfiguration("AzureCPConfig")
$config.ResetClaimTypesList()
$config.Update()
```

Hello,
thank you for your contribution.

Indeed, Nito.AsyncEx is not strongly signed and you need to do it yourself. This is the goal of package [Nivot.StrongNaming](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Nivot.StrongNaming/1.0.4.2) that is also part of the solution.
**Important**: you need to create your own private key to sign both AzureCP.dll and Nito.AsyncEx assemblies. This will generate a new AzureCP.dll with a public key different from the one in AzureCP.wsp package. 
For this reason, to avoid all possible confusions, I strongly recommend that you completely retract AzureCP.wsp solution before you deploy yours.

Exception: 'System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load file or assembly 'AzureCP, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=65dc6b5903b51636' or one of its dependencies. The system cannot find the file specified.  File name: 'AzureCP, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=65dc6b5903b51636'     at System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly._nLoad(AssemblyName fileName, String codeBase, Evidence assemblySecurity, RuntimeAssembly locationHint, StackCrawlMark& stackMark, IntPtr pPrivHostBinder, Boolean throwOnFileNotFound, Boolean forIntrospection, Boolean suppressSecurityChecks)     at System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly.InternalLoadAssemblyName(AssemblyName assemblyRef, Evidence assemblySecurity, RuntimeAssembly reqAss...	c220449e-60ed-204c-7fc8-a7ca75a067a2

65dc6b5903b51636 is the public key token of standard AzureCP.dll, so SharePoint is telling you that it doesn't find the standard AzureCP.dll.
Your own version of AzureCP.dll has a different public key token because you created your own private key to sign it (and create a strong named assembly).

In short, this error means that something tries to load the AzureCP.dll, so it is very likely that you did not completely uninstall the standard AzureCP.wsp package before you deployed your custom version (which overwrote all feature AzureCP deployed).

This is why I strongly recommended that you completely uninstall standard AzureCP.wsp before you start deploying your custom version.

Now the environment is a little bit messy. To fix it, I would suggest that you try the following;
- Completely retract and remove custom/standard AzureCP.wsp currently deployed
- Visit [this page](http://ldapcp.com/Fix-setup-issues.html) to make sure there is no AzureCP artifact left, and delete them if that's the case
**Note**: this page is for LDAPCP, but the principle is exactly the same for AzureCP, juste replace "LDAPCP" with "AzureCP"
- Once it's cleaned, deploy only your custom version of AzureCP.wsp

HTH

I took a first look at your changes.

Your logic assumes that nobody will ever want to add a guest user if he is in a registered domain. Are you 100% sure about that?

Besides, your logic works for search (e.g. find everyone starting with "user") since it consists of removing results from the list.

But SharePoint may want to validate such guest users (e.g. return 1 PickerEntity for "userX@domain.net"), which won't work anymore. This can't happen with your current implementation, but think about:
- Administrators who already deployed a previous version of AzureCP and added such guest users that you now exclude
- Administrators who may want to add such guest users anyway (back to my initial question)

One way to resolve this is to add a switch to the AzureCP admin page to enable/disable your filtering.
But still I'm very interested if it could make sense, in some scenario, to want to add guest users that are in a registered domain. What do you think?

On a side note, I wonder if we could find a better implementation of AzurecpResult, so that it could properly contain domains too, current solution works but it really looks like a quick & dirty solution.

I have a lenghly answer but let's be a bit shorter:

As per #3 B2B is kinda difficult. Works for microsoft accounts (MSA: google, hotmail) but not for B2B accounts between AADs.
The problem seems here to be in the claims forwarded by AAD.

So with this B2B between AADs you can pick the user from the picker but the access will be given to an "*#ext#@*.onmicrosoft.com" (* is a wildcard) but AAD with send the real mail address as identity.
For MSA it will provider the right claim so when invited you can pick it.

We do want people picker, otherwise just bypassing AAD lookup would have been suffisient.

We do also feel that people trying to use AzureCP with guest users have a hard time having it properly for both MSA and B2B between AADs.

Remember that the filter will only be effective if you have multiple tenant. We can discuss it, but i see no situation where you will invite in AAD a user from your own tenant.

In the end we do think that the filter is a good idea: 
it would prevent to give access that won't work.

Upgrade is a no brainer if you have only one AAD. If you have multiple AAD you might be pleased to 
- remove any modification made on claims in AzureCP and/or ADFS
- have a solution that works for all B2B users (MSA and B2B between AADs)
- have a clean people picker.

Inviting a guest user ("#ext#") from your known AADs? Really?  

I realy hope i can convice you that this filter is nothing bad.

I will nevertheless look at configuration if ok with you:
other than bypassing the filter, being able to indicate which AAD is federated with ADFS is usefull to prevent returning guest users from tenants that are not (the guest account needs to exist in a federated AAD to work)

I may also look further on AzurecpResult:
Maybe one result per tenant search containing a domain list and a directory object list might be better. than a raw object list.

Hi Cédric,

Here is my understanding of your design:
- A AAD Guest user won't be removed if his original domain (retrieved from his email) is not found in another AAD tenant registered in AzureCP.
- Only AAD Guest users that have their email suffix matching another AAD tenant registered in AzureCP are removed from results.

My main concern was if there would be any reason to not remove them, and you convinced me that no.
But in your last commit you added an option to activate/deactivate this filtering.
Does that mean you think otherwise now?

Note: I found [this article about B2B users](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/active-directory-b2b-user-properties), it helps me to better understand the differences between Guests and Members.

You are right in your first sentences.

Notice the last commit doesn't remove the filter.

What is does is indicate to only search for member user or all users for each tenant.

**Why doing that?**

The main scenario we are looking at is as follows:

```asciiart
                                           +----------------+
   +........AzureCP AAD Graph API..........| AAD seconday 1 | 
   :                                :     /+----------------+ 
+----+ SAML 1.0 +------+ SAML 2.0 +-------------+     +----------------+
| SP | -------- | ADFS | -------- | AAD primary |-B2B-| Guest Accounts |
+----+          +------+          +-------------+     +----------------+
   :                                      \+-----------------+
   +........AzureCP AAD Graph API..........| AAD secondary 2 |
                                           +-----------------+
```

What i know:
Guest can be in any tenants.
AAD can only authentify users he knows, is this a Member or a Guest.

If guest from a secondary tenant tries to login to sharepoint (s)he will be redirected to the primary AAD. 
This AAD will complain that there is no account for the guest user. 
Even if invited on both tenants, the guest will have a different UPN in both (guest1_gmail.com#ext#@Alice.onMicrosoft.com and guest1_gmail.com#ext#@Bob.onMicrosoft.com)

Federating to multiple AADs is possible. 

> REM: 
>
> This is some work to register sharepoint in each AAD.
> This will get confusing for guest users at home real discovery.
> The only advantage i see is lessen the invitation work

```asciiart
   ,....AAD Graph API..,
   :                   :
   :                +-------+   +----------------+
   :                | AAD 1 | - | Guest Accounts |
+----+    +------+ /+-------+   +----------------+
| SP | -- | ADFS |     | (optional B2B)
+----+    +------+ \+-------+   +----------------+
   :                | AAD 1 | - | Guest Accounts |
   :                +-------+   +----------------+
   :                   :
   '....AAD Graph API..'
```

So what i conclude:
**Guest users should only be used on AAD federated with Sharepoint**

Indicating with wich AAD a Sharepoint (trought ADFS) is federated allows to filter out guest users that should not be given access.

Hello, thank you for your feedback, and sorry but I think I don't understand what you propose.
I didn't know the AAD invitation API so I [found and read this](https://cloudblogs.microsoft.com/enterprisemobility/2016/10/31/azuread-b2b-invitation-api-is-now-in-public-preview/).
Can you make your point more explicit? 
Do you propose that AzureCP replaces the site invitation process of SharePoint (and not only the people picker lookup)?

We are trying out AzureCP for our solution.

Basicaly, we want to user AzureAD for sharepoint on permises and leverage B2B as well as MSA (i.e: hotmail).

We spotted few points that we would like to be able to handle:
1/Invitation
Authorization does work correctly for the different kind of users. but every user needs an account in azure ad, right. In B2B a guest would have a shadow account. 
So users needs to be first invited into azure ad before rights can be set to them in sharepoint. We are debating the use of an invitation portal that would allow to invite extern people. A example page does exist for that (https://github.com/Azure/active-directory-dotnet-graphapi-b2bportal-web if i am right).
We can't avoid feeling that there should be a more sharepoint integrated solution to that.
2/Groups
We wouldn't want to recreate groups from B2B tennants to provide access so we want to use claims enrichments to collect groups from the original tenant of B2B users (provided they are in an AzureAD).
To allow management from sharepoint we decided to configure extra azuread in azurecp thus allowing picking of extra groups.
3/People Picker
So we end up with a "main" azure ad which handles user authentication as well as B2B and MSA. But in people picker both the shadow account and the real account shows up. As discussed in another issue, B2B does work with a claims modification on ADFS level (from #ext to normal upn). But this modification might not be welcome for MSA accounts.
In the end we tought possible to filter out "shadow" accounts from B2B users and only use the information form their native tenant if provided by an azure ad (i.e. main tenant emailaddress match another known tenant upn).

So:
- invitation process: we may have to look in another direction
- shadow accounts: we d'like to correlate shadow account and account from other known tenants to detect shadows and hide them.

Hello,
You can use ADFS as an intermediate between SharePoint and Azure AD. 
ADFS will get the SAML 2.0 token from Azure AD and generate a proper SAML 1.1 token that SharePoint can understand.
In this scenario SharePoint trusts ADFS (and its signing certificate).
The configuration to make is described in [this blog post](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/mrochon/2017/04/07/using-azure-ad-to-enable-partner-access-sharepoint).

Hello, yes you can now federate Azure AD directly with SharePoint, which is very good news since you don't need ADFS anymore.

Hi @stevep4 
AzureCP can fix the display name of users if:
- User is added for the very first time in the site collection (if user was deleted and is re-added this won't work)
- In central admin > Security > AzureCP claims mapping page: a Graph property has the Metadata "DisplayName" set

But, whatever you configure this or not, the User Profile Application service is the component that synchronizes the display name from the User Profiles to the site collections.
So if your trusted users have a valid user profile in the UPA, their display name will be synced from this profile.

Hello, it's very dependent on your environment so it's not possible to provide an example ready to use.
Below is the script I use to configure the trust with my AAD tenant, which uses Azure ACS to issue the SAML token:

```powershell
# Register root certificate
$rootCert = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2("C:\Data\Claims\acs signing cert.cer")
New-SPTrustedRootAuthority -Name "Azure ACS signing certificate" -Certificate $rootCert

# Define claim types
$email = New-SPClaimTypeMapping "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "EmailAddress" -SameAsIncoming
$role = New-SPClaimTypeMapping "http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/role" -IncomingClaimTypeDisplayName "Role" -SameAsIncoming

$signingCert = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2("C:\Data\Claims\acs signing cert.cer")
$realm = "https://ycollabsp13.collab.yvanhost.local"
$signinurl = "https://XXXX.accesscontrol.windows.net/v2/wsfederation"

# Create a new SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer in SharePoint
$t=New-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer -Name "YvandAzure" -Description "Yvand MSDN Azure" -Realm $realm -ImportTrustCertificate $signingCert -ClaimsMappings $email,$role -SignInUrl $signinurl -IdentifierClaim $email.InputClaimType

# Update additional settings
$t.UseWReplyParameter=$true
$uri = New-Object System.Uri($signinurl)
$t.ProviderSignOutUri=$uri
$t.ClaimProviderName="AzureCP"
$t.Update()

```
that is perfect. thanks so much !!!

AzureCP expects that you always use property UserPrincipalName for users, because AAD sets the main claim type (http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name) with this property, and SAML token doesn't contain the email address. Then in ACS or ADFS, you may transform this claim type in either http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/upn or http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress but it's still the same AAD property (UserPrincipalName). Below is from the SAML token that login.microsoftonline.com posted to the user upon successful authentication, the value matches the property UserPrincipalName (which is called "User name" in https://portal.azure.com): ```xml AzureUser1@TENANT.onmicrosoft.com ```

Hi @benpea,
sorry for the late reply. I reproduced your issue, and you are correct:
- For B2B (guest) users: AAD does not issue claim http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name that would contain userPrincipalName value (typically "yvand_external.com#EXT#@TENANT.onmicrosoft.com"), instead it issues claims http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress with the actual email of the user.
- For normal (member) users: AAD issues claim http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name that contains userPrincipalName value (typically "AzureUser1@TENANT.onmicrosoft.com"), and it does not issue email claim.

On the other hand, AzureCP always sets the identity permission with the userPrincipalName value, so indeed this doesn't work for B2B users since AAD does not send this attribute.
Are you using ACS or ADFS between SharePoint and AAD?

A possible solution that does not require any change on AzureCP is to configure ADFS to retrieve the userPrincipalName of the B2B users and issue it with the identity claim type set on SharePoint.
This solution cannot be done with ACS.
Does this sound like a possible solution for you?

We've resolved this issue.

The problem was SamAccountName and Email were both configured as primary claims vs as secondary mappings (Like how  DisplayName is configured by default)

The solution was to delete the email & samAcountName configurations and add them back in using 'New Item' in the Claims configuration page, then using the 'add a mapping between a LDAP object and the main corresponding object type' 

Now when the user is selected they are added with the primary identifier claims as a User object.

Thanks!

By design, SharePoint will never consider that an AD and an ADFS user are the same, because they come from 2 different authentication providers.

You can set what attribute is used to create group claims, and by default it's the samAccountName: Go to Central Administration > Security > LDAPCP Claim types configuration.
You can also double check how LDAPCP creates groups claims by filtering SharePoint logs on product/area "LDAPCP" (enable verbose to see individual groups)

Hi @NaveenKanukuntla, your analysis is perfectly correct:
In this code path, LDAPCP uses the DistinguishedName of the group to set its claim value, regardless of what is set in the claims mapping table.
The reason for this design is that the LDAP object available here is the user. The only info LDAPCP has about the groups is their DistinguishedName values in property memberof of the user.
To actually set the claim value of groups with their samAccountName, LDAPCP would need to do 1 additional LDAP query for each group, which may have a significant impact on performance.

A possible alternative is to get the groups using method LDAPCP.GetGroupsFromActiveDirectory(), which should set the claim value of group with their samAccountName. For that you need to check the option "Use .NET helper (for Active Directory only)" in LDAPCP global configuration page. Did you consider it?

I see that all connections are made with AuthenticationType "SimpleBind", while I guess you set something more secure?
To confirm if that's the actual issue, you can run the script below that gets group membership just like LDAPCP does when "Use .NET Helper" is set.
You only need to set variables at the top:

```powershell
Add-Type -AssemblyName System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement
$ldapUser = "contoso\spfarm"
if (!$ldapPassword) { $ldapPassword = Read-Host "Enter the password (will appear in clear text)" }
$userToAugment = "yvand"
$domainFQDN = "contoso.local"
# domainContainer must be set, otherwise UserPrincipal.FindByIdentity throsws error 0x80005000 (tested only in AD)
$domainContainer = "DC=contoso,DC=local"
$contextOptions = [System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.ContextOptions] "Negotiate, Signing, Sealing" # Encrypted connection, traffic unreadable in network analyzer
$contextOptions = [System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.ContextOptions] "SimpleBind" # LDAP traffic is in clear text
$contextType = [System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.ContextType]::Domain

$principalContext = $null
$principalContext = New-Object System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.PrincipalContext ($contextType, $domainFQDN, $domainContainer, $contextOptions, $ldapUser, $ldapPassword)
if ($principalContext -ne $null -and [String]::IsNullOrEmpty($principalContext.ConnectedServer) -eq $false) {
    $principalContext
    $user = $null
    $user = [System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.UserPrincipal]::FindByIdentity($principalContext, $userToAugment)
    $groups = $user.GetAuthorizationGroups()

    # The foreach group calls an enumerator that does separate LDAP binds for each group
    foreach($group in $groups) {
        $group.SamAccountName
    }
}
```

A given "PickerEntity metadata" can be associated to only 1 LDAP attribute (per LDAP class).
You may clear the "PickerEntity metadata" for the windowsaccountname claim type and use PowerShell to set it to either "cn" or "sn", but it don't think it will affect the test in the tooltip
As I understood, there is rather no such functionality that sn or cn will be replaced by the "DisplayName" value and the search will only follow these attributes but will be displayed something else?

There is no direct way to control the value shown in the tooltip, but the order of the list may matter: if you put the displayName on top of the cs/sn, I think it will show the displayName in the tooltip

@camel028 there is no way to control the value displayed in the tool tip, LDAPCP chooses the first attribute that matches the input, and formats it as you mentioned...

This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

Can you check if the claim types in your SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer match the claim types configured by default by LDAPCP?
You can see them at central admin > security > LDAPCP Claim types configuration.
If they don't match you need to add them here

Well, I found the issue and I was a bit stupid.
I forgot that our SharePoint Servers are in a different domain than our user accounts. After I added the LDAP connection in the global settings, it started working.

Ok, so I have solved the problem by adding the role claim via PowerShell

`$web = Get-SPWeb "https://sharepoint.com"
$claim = New-SPClaimsPrincipal -TrustedIdentityTokenIssuer “ADFS” -ClaimValue “R-App-SharePoint" -ClaimType “http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/role“
$group = $web.Groups[“Visitors“]
$group.AddUser($claim.ToEncodedString(), “”, “R-App-SharePoint", “”)`

Hi @arzusah
- User Profile service does not play any role in the user authorization flow. You can actually remove it and it will not change anything to the way you grant permissions.
- By default, LDAPCP queries the AD the SharePoint server belongs to, but this can be customized in central admin > security > LDAPCP global config page. From here you can define a new LDAP connection and restrict its path to a specific OU.
- You should always assign LDAPCP to only 1 trustedidentityprovider. If you assign it to 0 or several, it will not work.

Can you guide me to how I can filter to a specific OU?

No, you can add as many LDAP domains as you need in LDAPCP.
To filter to a specific OU, you just need to include the OU to the path, for example: `LDAP://XXXX.YYY/OU=Users,DC=XXXX,DC=YYY`

@larkoize you are correct, LDAPCP does not rely on property UserAccountDirectoryPath.
Due to limitations of SharePoint API, LDAPCP has no reliable way to determine the current site collection fore sure in all scenarios, so unfortunately, there is no solution for your issue...

As shown in [LDAPCP.Developers](https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/releases/download/14.1.20191007.981/LDAPCP.Developers.zip), the LDAPCP administration pages must contain the information about the custom claims provider.
For example, in LdapcpSettings.aspx:

```
<Ldapcp:GlobalSettings ID="LdapcpGlobalSettings" Runat="server" ClaimsProviderName="<%# CustomConfiguration.ClaimsProviderName %>" PersistedObjectName="<%# CustomConfiguration.CONFIG_NAME %>" PersistedObjectID="<%# CustomConfiguration.CONFIG_ID %>" />
```

Do they have this information in your environment?
@Yvand that was the issue! The value for ClaimsProviderName was incorrect. Thanks!

@khalilG indeed, you should not use this approach to force the login mode, it has side effects like the one you noticed.
Instead, you should add a custom login page to bypasse the default one and force users to use the authN mode of your choice. You can take a look at https://github.com/Yvand/SPBypassLoginPage, which deploys such page

It can. There are 2 scenarios:
- User is added for the 1st time to the site collection: email used to send invitation is determined by LDAPCP.
- User already exists in the site collection (in UserInfo list): email used to send invitation is determined by his local profile, synchronized by the User Profile Application.

To determine the guilty component, I suggest you try to repro in a new test site collection.
Also, if you set LDAPCP logs to verboseEx like this:

```
"LDAPCP:*"| Set-SPLogLevel -TraceSeverity VerboseEx
```

Then the logs will record the email (relevant only if user is added for the 1st time to the site collection):

```
04/20/2020 17:13:56.21	w3wp.exe (0x1F9C)	0x0D54	LDAPCP	Claims Picking	1337	VerboseEx	[LDAPCP] Set metadata 'Email' of new entity to 'yvand@conto2016.local'	3fa54a9f-99f1-4003-37ac-5e75d7176454
04/20/2020 17:13:56.21	w3wp.exe (0x1F9C)	0x0D54	LDAPCP	Claims Picking	1337	Verbose	[LDAPCP] Added entity: display text: 'yvand@conto2016.local', claim value: 'yvand@conto2016.local', claim type: 'http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress'	3fa54a9f-99f1-4003-37ac-5e75d7176454
```

With current configuration, LDAPCP calls [UserPrincipal.FindByIdentity()](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.directoryservices.accountmanagement.userprincipal.findbyidentity?view=netframework-4.8) to get the identity of the user but it doesn't find it, probably because it doesn't query the employee id attribute.

Instead, in LDAPCP global configuration page > augmentation section: You should uncheck the option "Use .NET helper (for Active Directory only)" next to the LDAP connection.
It should fix the augmentation but it will only get the direct group membership of the users (not netsted groups)

Hello,
Indeed, you cannot use LDAPCP with 2 SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer, this is actually due to a SharePoint limitation.
The solution is to use 2 flavors of LDAPCP: one is the pure standard one, the other is basically LDAPCP with a different, unique name (e.g. CustomLDAPCP). Each has its unique configuration (persisted object) and name.
I used to provide a zip that contained a sample project to illustrate how to do that, but I did not release it for a while. I will make if for the latest version and update this thread when it is available.

@schrockmatthew when working with groups you need to be careful with their claim value.
As you can see in LDAPCP claim types mapping page, by default, LDAPCP uses prefix "{fqdn}\\" for groups. It means that for each value it gets from LDAP server, it adds "domainFQDN\\".
So it LDAP server returns "group1", LDAPCP creates permission "contoso.local\group1"
I don't know if this is the cause of your problem, but you need to compare the value of groups returned by your STS (ADFS) with the value set by LDAPCP. Both must match

It was {fqdn}\ in the prefix removal. Thanks for the reply

I can actually reproduce the same issue if I have both Windows and ADFS authentication modes enabled.
This is because both modes return 1 user, so SharePoint ends up with 2 users while it expects exactly 1.
This is indeed quite unexpected, and it occurs because SharePoint behaves as if it is looking up the value (which means all claims providers may return a result), instead of validating it (which means only the relevant claims provider should return a result).
I don't see an easy configuration to prevent this, it looks more like an issue with the edit page itself.

Hi Yvand, Thank you for your response. this is fixed by cleaning LDAPCP and reinstalling from scratch. I believe something might have gone wrong. The sequence I followed was to install LDAPCP, configured UPSA and Sync connection. however, there was an issue with LDAP port. when that fixed, the above issue appeared. So, it seems there was something went wrong and fixed after fresh installation

Good news, I found the root cause and upcoming version 14 will fix it. If you are interested, here are the details about the bug:

## Context
The issue occurs when LDAPCP uses the LDAP (AD) connection of the SharePoint server.
At some point LDAPCP gets the domain name by reading the LDAP property “distinguishedName” from the object DirectoryEntry:

https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/blob/a5c164680f44fbf778446bc91b0f59f887f557a5/LDAPCP/LDAPCPConfig.cs#L1290

Reading this property triggers an authenticated LDAP call to the AD server, using the creds of the application pool account (LDAPCP does privilege elevation).

## Root cause
But this privilege elevation was missing in 2 entry points: in [LDAPCP.GetClaimTypeForUserKey()](https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/blob/a5c164680f44fbf778446bc91b0f59f887f557a5/LDAPCP/LDAPCP.cs#L1916) and [LDAPCP.GetUserKeyForEntity()](https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/blob/a5c164680f44fbf778446bc91b0f59f887f557a5/LDAPCP/LDAPCP.cs#L1948).
So from those methods, connection to AD server was attempted as “NT AUTHORITY\IUSR” (the default anonymous account), which of course failed: lsass was issuing a Kerberos TGS to SPN “krbtgt/NT AUTHORITY” (assuming NT AUTHORITY was an AD domain name).
This is what caused the DirectoryServicesCOMException.

## Solution
I added the missing privilege elevation in method LDAPCP.GetUserKeyForEntity():

https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/blob/a5c164680f44fbf778446bc91b0f59f887f557a5/LDAPCP/LDAPCP.cs#L1953-L1956

But doing so in LDAPCP.GetClaimTypeForUserKey() is not possible: it causes a StackOverflowException. 
So to fully fix the issue I implemented a different way to read the domain name in this scenario, and little other improvements.
The commits that fix the bug are those with #87 in their title:

- https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/commit/653e1d9f17f301474b41df089fd23b2569d283cb
- https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/commit/8b024e268a4b499c97916e39674dde1430b0ffdb
- https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/commit/c7daef4d197b844add2cdc0a75e1c916ad724b4f
- https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/commit/a5c164680f44fbf778446bc91b0f59f887f557a5
- https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/commit/dee7f5e2684f80fce9db48c0d3cd8a5668f246d9

Upcoming version 14 will contain the fix. I will publish it as soon as possible, with hopefully a pre-release today if unit tests pass.
The pre-release that fixes this bug is https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/releases/tag/14.0.20190821.952

No, not just with certificate, there will be username/password. I believe current implementation of LDAPCP communicates to LDAP via port 389. As it will send username/password as clear text we need to use port 636. To use via port 636 we need to package certificate with the request. @domsen123 LDAPCP stores all its configuration in a SharePoint persisted object, in the configuration database. You can view it by running this SQL command:

```sql
SELECT Id, Name, cast (properties as xml) AS XMLProps FROM Objects WHERE Name = 'LdapcpConfig'
```

To update its configuration, such as the password, I strongly recommend that you use PowerShell, as described in https://ldapcp.com/Configure-LDAPCP.html

@domsen123 You can update it with PowerShell like this:

```powershell
Add-Type -AssemblyName "ldapcp, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=80be731bc1a1a740"
$config = [ldapcp.LDAPCPConfig]::GetConfiguration("LDAPCPConfig")
```

@Anagirl921sorry for my late reply, yes it's possible with some SharePoint configuration, but LDAPCP can do nothing about this.
A good way is to set property SPPeoplePickerSettings.ActiveDirectoryCustomFilter with a fake filter, for example : 

```powershell
$wa = Get-SPWebApplication "http://sp16/"
# Some users like super user / super reader / crawl account should have this value in AD, so they can be resolved when SharePoint uses them
$wa.PeoplePickerSettings.ActiveDirectoryCustomFilter = " (&(telephoneNumber=00110011)) "
$wa.Update() 
```

As the comment says, it's very important that super user / super reader / crawl account have this value in AD, so they can be resolved when SharePoint uses them

For a while, LDAPCP ensures thread safety by using class [ReaderWriterLockSlim](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.threading.readerwriterlockslim?view=netframework-4.7.2), and I do load tests to ensure that thread safety is working correctly.
Besides, LDAPCP does not use Dictionary class.
So if you use a recent version of LDAPCP (greater than 5.1), I'm very confident that it cannot cause such issue.

Thank you for your answer - our conclusion for now is that assigned resources for the frontend servers where not adequate - and that the problem was solved with extra resources and extra front end servers.

Through UI:
Go to Central Administration > Security > LDAPCP Claim types configuration page > Edit the claim type where you want to set the prefix > Set the prefix in column "Prefix to bypass lookup"

Through PowerShell:
```powershell
Add-Type -AssemblyName "ldapcp, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=80be731bc1a1a740"
$config = [ldapcp.LDAPCPConfig]::GetConfiguration("LDAPCPConfig")
$ctConfig = $config.ClaimTypes.GetByClaimType("http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress")
$ctConfig.PrefixToBypassLookup = "ext:"
$config.Update()
```

Hi, you need to clarify what value you expect (what is issued in the SAML token by the 3rd party STS), and what value (LDAP attribute) you map in LDAPCP.
What you describe suggests that thoses values are not the same, which is why permission is not granted.

I don't have a AD LDS to verify this, but I think you need to update the LDAP object class to match the class of UserProxy accounts.
You can do this in central admin > Security > LDAPCP claim types configuration page
perfect answer, cheers!

Hi @richjnsn 
Yes, this is possible: the idea is that you define a keywork for a given claim type.
Then, when user types the keyword in the people picker, what is after will be validated as-is. E.g.:
- You set keyword "ext:" on claim type email
- In the people picker you type "ext:email@partner.com" and LDAPCP validates "email@partner.com"

To set the keyword, go to central admin > LDAPCP claim types configuration > Edit the claim type you want > Set the keyword in column "Prefix to bypass lookup"

indeed, the setting is not shown in the UI anymore, but you can still set it with PowerShell, e.g.:
```powershell
Add-Type -AssemblyName "ldapcp, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=80be731bc1a1a740"
$config = [ldapcp.LDAPCPConfig]::GetConfiguration("LDAPCPConfig")

$ctConfig = $config.ClaimTypes | ? {$_.ClaimType -eq "http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/primarygroupsid"}
# v11 (not published yet) has a new method GetByClaimType():
$ctConfig = $config.ClaimTypes.GetByClaimType("http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/primarygroupsid")
$ctConfig.ShowClaimNameInDisplayText = $false

$config.Update()
```

The behaviour of the AD when sending the "\b" search is a bit strange, but possibly a deviation from the RFC.

To our understanding it should work, if the query string sent to the LDAP escapes the "\" to "\5C". This should suffice for all LDAP-Server, not only AD.
Do you have the opportunity to check the proposed change?

To be honest, no, sorry.
Can you please give clear example(s) of how LDAPCP should change the input (before/after)?
Can you also test your proposed change using the [PowerShell script here](https://ldapcp.com/Troubleshoot-LDAPCP.html) and confirm if it works?

We got to test the changes with the script:

![ldapcp_org](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36055687/42039114-ed3c68da-7aec-11e8-93b7-29b41e38749b.png)

![ldapcp_cor](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36055687/42039665-38675ca6-7aee-11e8-83c4-ab015e0e0032.png)


We are using the admindisplayname for filtering, but the problem is independent from it. As soon as a "\" followed by a hexadecimal character is in the searched string, the search fails. Replacing of "\" to "\5c" solves the issue.

Therefore we recommend a general replacement of the "\" character in the searched strings for attributes with "\5c".
Is the provided information sufficient and clear?

I created a group with the name "group\specialchar":
In AD it was created with following properties:
- LDAP attribute "name" = group\specialchar
- LDAP attribute "sAMAccountName" = group_specialchar

I made following tests using [this PowerShell script](https://ldapcp.com/Troubleshoot-LDAPCP.html):
$filter = "(&(objectClass=group)(name=group\special*))"
=> Returns the group as expected

$filter = "(&(objectClass=group)(name=group\5cspecial*))"
=> Returns the group as expected

So it's still not clear to me what scenario is not working, and if you could provide text examples instead of screenshots, it will be far more easier for me to understand.

As mentioned earlier, the problem only occurs, when after the \ the group starts with a hexadecimal character (0-9a-f). So "group\specialchar" works fine (even though according the standard this should not work either, because all \ have to be encoded).
A better example would be: "group\acharacter".  Searching "group\achar*" will yield nothing and "group\5cachar*" will yield the group.

The encoding of special characters can be found for example in
https://ldap.com/ldap-dns-and-rdns/

If someone wants to go crazy, the other characters would be nice to, to be encoded too. But \ should cover most of the cases.
I just realized all my "\\" got replaced to "\" after sending. Sorry if that made earlier text a bit confusing.

Hi @Albino1006, unfortunately, due to a design limitation in SharePoint, it's not possible to apply a different filter per site collection:
During the permission creation process, SharePoint passes the URL of the web application (to LDAPCP), instead of the URL of the current site collection.
This behavior affects all custom claims providers.
Something was wrong with my User Profile Application. I cleared the SP config cache on all servers and everything is back to normal, including the LDAPCP settings.

Hi @Albino1006, due to SharePoint API limitations, you cannot use LDAPCP for 2 different SPTrustedLoginProvider.
To workaround this, you can:
- use standard LDAPCP.wsp for 1 SPTrustedLoginProvider
- use a [custom LDAPCP](http://ldapcp.com/For-Developers.html) for the other SPTrustedLoginProvider

Hello, unfortunately this happens sometimes, it's like the persisted object that LDAPCP creates and uses to store its config does not belong to LDAPCP anymore.
In this scenario, the only way is to delete that persisted object, so that LDAPCP creates it again. This is possible using stsadm.exe, located in "C:\Program Files\Common Files\microsoft shared\Web Server Extensions\15\BIN":
```
stsadm -o deleteconfigurationobject -id 5D306A02-A262-48AC-8C44-BDB927620227
```
Then, return to LDAPCP administration page and LDAPCP will create a new persisted object (config).
Note that deleting the persisted object will also delete the existing configuration.

Hi @Yvand .. yes that did.  Thanks for your help!

"Check permission" feature relies on a special (called non-interactive) token that has a lifetime of 24h by default.
So after you enabled augmentation in LDAPCP, you need to wait at least 24h to be sure you use a non-interactive token that had a chance to be augmented by LDAPCP.
If you don't want to wait, here is how you can change its lifetime:
```powershell
$cs = [Microsoft.SharePoint.Administration.SPWebService]::ContentService
$cs.TokenTimeout = New-TimeSpan -Minutes 1
$cs.Update() 
```
It's default value is [1440 minutes](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/office/microsoft.sharepoint.administration.spwebservice.tokentimeout.aspx?f=255&MSPPError=-2147217396).
You need to restart IIS on all servers after that.

People picker stores results in a local storage cache in the browser. 
I thought this was the reason why you got disabled users, and why I initially asked you to try in a new site collection (results are stored per site collection).
To clear it, you can use the developer's toolbar of the the browser (press F12) and run this in the console:
```javascript
localStorage.clear();
```
After that, old results should be gone

The filtering is done in LDAPCP.ProcessLdapResults() method.
There can be a lot of reasons why a result is removed by the filtering. 
If you want, you can clone the source code, download the 
symbols from [LDAPCP_Debug.zip](https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/releases) and live debug to find out why it is excluded.
It's heavy but it will work...

Hi @eduralph, there are too many reasons to filter out a potential result to record that in SharePoint logs, even in Verbose(Ex):
LDAPCP parses each LDAP attribute of each LDAP result, and keep only relevant values (to transform in PickerEntity result) based on many criteria. 
In case you want to take a look, this logic is implemented in [method LDAPCP.ProcessLdapResults()](https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/blob/0f18b52b898d4e832b4b91f3961d4afbfce9f857/LDAPCP/LDAPCP.cs#L735-L827)

The PrincipalOperationException exception is thrown because of a bug in .NET (in System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.dll).
It is expected to be fixed in both.NET 4.6.2 and .NET 4.7.1, which should ship with the January 2018 updates of .NET.
Once the fix is installed, nested groups should work fine. 
Until then, all user membership operations which get this exception will fallback to LDAP query, which does not get the nested groups, as you noticed.
Technically it's possible to update LDAPCP to get nested groups but it would be quite a big work to do (e.g. handle special cases like when group is not in the same domain).

Hi @matthieu-bt 

Indeed, by default LDAPCP expects that objectclass of users is "user", but you can change this if you delete and recreate the mapping in LDAPCP page "claims mapping".

But as you noticed, you cannot specify a different objectclass based on the LDAP server it is hitting. 

In theory, you could specify a different LDAP filter for each LDAP server if you created a custom version of LDAPCP and override method LDAPCP.GetLDAPFilter().
The method sets the LDAP filter per LDAP server.
The query would work as you wish but it would fail later during the processing of the results, because LDAPCP expects that there is 1 objectclass per object type.
Unfortunately, changing the design to fit your need would be a huge work.

The best solution I can think of is to use an objectclass that would fit all LDAP servers, You can set this objectclass in LDAPCP "claims mapping" page for each claim type that represents a user.
Would that be possible?

Hi @kurky91, thank you for the clear explanation.

I understand the need but this sounds very specific and requires some effort to update the admin page to propose this new setting while not making it confusing.

Besides, you can already do what you want by creating a custom version of LDAPCP and override method GetLDAPServers(RequestInformation). 
Object RequestInformation contains the type of operation (augmentation, search, validation), so you can return a LDAP path different based on that.

You can find more information on http://ldapcp.com/For-Developers.html and practical example in "LDAPCP.Developers.zip" that you can find with each [LDAPCP release](https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/releases).

The drawback is that it's of course more work than just deploying LDAPCP, and you would lose the administration pages unless you create additional code to be able to use them with your own claims provider.
Would this be an option for you?

Hi Albino,

LDAPCP does what it is asked by SharePoint: a lookup based on the input (supplied as a string) that should return all results found.
You are hitting a design limit of SharePoint implementation: input as a string always triggers a lookup that can return 1 to many results.

It's only when input is supplied as a SPClaim that (custom) claims provider must return exactly 1 result.

There is nothing that can be done in LDAPCP to mitigate that, except what you already found: force LDAPCP to always do an exact LDAP lookup. But even that may not work if the input (string) matches values of multiple LDAP attributes (e.g. sAMAccountName and givenname, or mail and userPrincipalName).

- If the SPTrustedLoginProvider is enabled in any zone of a web application, it is expected that LDAPCP returns results regardless of the current zone where people picker is used. The short explanation is that this is because of a SharePoint limitation and there is no choice.

- If the SPTrustedLoginProvider is not enabled in any zone of a web application, LDAPCP should not return any result. I tried and I cannot reproduce your behavior.
You can try to update to the latest version (actually, you should because it's much better) but I don't remember a specific change that fixes this in particular.
You can also check SharePoint logs and filter on Product/Area "LDAPCP" to try to get more info but I don't think they will be very useful for this particular issue.

Hi @MiikkaLehtonen, 
As the log mentioned, SharePoint expects to use claims provider SPTrustedBackedByActiveDirectoryClaimProvider but since it's LDAPCP, it stops.

SPTrustedBackedByActiveDirectoryClaimProvider is a quite special, hidden claims provider that was implemented to ease migration from Windows claims to trusted authN.
It is never visible or used explicitely, the only way to use it is to create the SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer object using the "-UseDefaultConfiguration" switch, as documented in [kb3042604](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/3042604/the-convert-spwebapplication-command-cannot-convert-from-windows-claim).

So the short answer for you would be to delete the SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer and recreate it with the "-UseDefaultConfiguration" switch.
This will "disconnect" LDAPCP from the trust and link SPTrustedBackedByActiveDirectoryClaimProvider to it instead.

Unfortunately, due to the implementation of SPTrustedBackedByActiveDirectoryClaimProvider, it's very likely not going to work in your scenario: 
the problem is the value used to set the entity key of each entity (aka user):
SPTrustedBackedByActiveDirectoryClaimProvider uses specifically the SID of users (remember it's used to migrate winclaims to trusted authN), but:
- I suspect SharePoint doesn't even get the SID of users in your scenario.
- LDAPCP uses the identity claim type for the entity key.

This difference means that if you switch to SPTrustedBackedByActiveDirectoryClaimProvider, you will mess up your trusted users permissions.

So, I don't know how to resolve your issue, but I would search for a way that doesn't involve using SPTrustedBackedByActiveDirectoryClaimProvider, if possible.

Unfortunately you need to redo all the steps in http://ldapcp.com/Fix-setup-issues.html.
But after that you also need to run this stsadm command to delete the LDAPCP persisted object:
```
stsadm -o deleteconfigurationobject -id 5D306A02-A262-48AC-8C44-BDB927620227
```
No worries about this command, it deletes only the LDAPCP persisted object.
If you want to see how this persisted object looks like, you can run this SQL command in SharePoint config database:
```sql
SELECT * FROM [13_SharePoint_Config].[dbo].[Objects] WHERE Id LIKE '5D306A02-A262-48AC-8C44-BDB927620227'
```

If I may suggest something else (years after): Insted of setting the ClaimProviderName-Member on the authenticationProvider, you may try:

`
$cp = Get-SPClaimProvider "<name goes here>";
$ap = Get-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer;
**Set-SPTrustedIdentityTokenIssuer -Identity $ap -ClaimProvider $cp**
`

This will configure the Authentication Provider using dedicated objects instead of "reference by string" and ... worked for me. Reinstalling my claimProvider unfortunately did not do the trick.

Hi @swanle 
LDAPCP searches an entry with entity 'FormsRole' or 'SecurityGroup', and uses its claim type for the groups it creates if augmentation is enabled.
If there is none, augmentation does not happen.
By default claim type http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/role is set with 'FormsRole', so (if LDACP augmentation is enabled), groups will be created with this claim type.
Does it make sense?

You can use [procdump from sysinternals](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/procdump) like this:
