The LDAP search returned 17 results, but one of the user does not have his identity attribute (mail) set, which causes the ArgumentOutOfRangeException exception. This user was found based on its cn, sn or displayname attribute.

This is a flaw in the LDAPCP logic: this kind of user should be detected and excluded, so that other results can be processed.
I'm writing a fix for this and a new version will be available soon.

One important NOTE for everyone who troubleshoot augmentation. ### Important note Following LDAP server connection is **incorrect** (even if `Test LDAP connection` works) **you should use `distinguished name` of LDAP server** ### What's going on [0x80005000](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/ADSI/generic-adsi-error-codes) means `An invalid ADSI pathname was passed.` (Verify that the object exists on the directory server and check for typographic errors of the path.) If you take a look at the code https://github.com/Yvand/LDAPCP/blob/985b2079381bca166b291eb1ff4f34fcce5a09d1/LDAPCP/LDAPCPConfig.cs#L950-L969 you will see that LDAPCP build `domainFQDN` using `DC`s, if they omitted `domainFQDN` will be equal to `String.Empty` and when you turn on `This is an Active Directory server, use UserPrincipal.GetAuthorizationGroups` on this LDAP Server you will see following error in logs ``` [LDAPCP] Unexpected error occurred while getting AD groups of user my_name@domain.com in LDAP://my.domain.com using UserPrincipal.GetAuthorizationGroups(): System.Runtime.InteropServices.COMException: Unknown error (0x80005000), Callstack: at System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry.Bind(Boolean throwIfFail) at System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry.Bind() at System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry.get_AdsObject() at System.DirectoryServices.PropertyValueCollection.PopulateList() at System.DirectoryServices.PropertyValueCollection..ctor(DirectoryEntry entry, String propertyName) at System.DirectoryServices.PropertyCollection.get_Item(String propertyName) at System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.PrincipalContext.DoLDAPDirectoryInitNoContainer() at System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.PrincipalContext.DoDomainInit() at System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.PrincipalContext.Initialize() at System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.PrincipalContext.get_QueryCtx() at System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.Principal.FindByIdentityWithTypeHelper(PrincipalContext context, Type principalType, Nullable`1 identityType, String identityValue, DateTime refDate) at System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.Principal.FindByIdentityWithType(PrincipalContext context, Type principalType, String identityValue) at System.DirectoryServices.AccountManagement.UserPrincipal.FindByIdentity(PrincipalContext context, String identityValue) at ldapcp.LDAPCP.GetGroupsFromActiveDirectory(LDAPConnection ldapConnection, OperationContext currentContext, ClaimTypeConfig groupCTConfig) ``` @Yvand do not you mind to mention it in docs? or even better, improve `Test LDAP connection` validation?

hello, the people picker (so LDAPCP here) doesn't use what ADFS sends, it uses its own configuration to query LDAP server and display results.
If you want to show the display name in the people picker, go to central administration > security > LDAPCP global configuration: in section "Display of permissions created with identity claim", type property displayName in "Display another LDAP attribute"

Sure! You have to make sure the ORDER of your mappings are correct and also the last powershell tag on your command uses -IdentifierClaim $upnclaimmap.InputClaimType  Anotherwords, make sure the UPN is your main claim (Which is what is set in Active Directory for each user) and in the Claim Mapping config in the “Attirbute to display” I use the “cn” (common name) attribute which is their full display name.  With that, it started working beautifully.

Technically, the reason why LDAPCP doesn't query contacts is because LDAP object class of users is set to "user".
To include contacts, you can try to change it to "person", which includes both users and contacts (at least in Active Directory).
But I never tested this, I don't know if this would work fine.
You can make this change in central administration > security > LDAPCP claims mapping.
Can you give it a try?

@hkusanic I reviewed the code and it looks great :)
But I made further changes:
- Removed LDAPCP.GetLDAPServerDirectories method because it duplicates LDAPCP.GetLDAPServers
- Moved ResolveNetBiosDomainName method to class RequestInformation so that it can be called by LDAPCP class as well
- Updated LDAPCP.GetLDAPServers to retrieve NetBIOS name is it's not already set in the persisted object

But I think I found a bug in RequestInformation.ResolveDomainFromDirectoryPath(string directory):
When directory value looks like "YDCCollab.collab.YvanHost.local/dc=collab,dc=YvanHost,dc=local" method returns an empty dnsDomainName. This is bad because the domainname is not added correctly to claim values configured with a dynamic token.
As far as I can see it fails in RequestInformation.ResolveDnsDomainName, can you please take a look?

I pushed the changes in a new branch hkusanic-pr/netBiosName in my repo, normally that should sync with your own repo but I'm missing some knowledge here, maybe we can sync together to check this :)

@hkusanichttps://github.com/hkusanic I reviewed the code and it looks great :)
But I made some changes in the code:
-   Removed one LDAPCP.GetLDAPServerDirectories method
-   Moved ResolveNetBiosDomainName method to RequestInformation so that it can be called by LDAPCP class as well
-   Updated LDAPCP.GetLDAPServers to retrieve NetBIOS name is if's not set in the persisted object

But I think I found a bug in RequestInformation.ResolveDomainFromDirectoryPath(string directory):
When directory value looks like "YDCCollab.collab.YvanHost.local/dc=collab,dc=YvanHost,dc=local" method returns an empty dnsDomainName. This is bad because the domainname is not added correctly to claim values configured with a dynamic token.
As far as I can see it fails in RequestInformation.ResolveDnsDomainName, can you please take a look?

I pushed the changes in a new branch hkusanic-pr/netBiosName in my repo, normally that should sync with your own repo but I'm missing some knowledge here, maybe we can sync together to check this :)
